reviewText: There is no doubt that Jullian Fellowes can spin a yarn, but fear has clouded his artistry.  I think the hardest reality to face is that the writer did not trust his fans; and that is such a shame.  After loosing Dan Stevens (Matthew Crawley), fans were dismayed and hurt; but that was not Follows fault.  He did his best to secure the actor but in the end, Mathew Crawley must be killed off.Now, this adds a great deal of writing possibilities for season 4, as all the fans go through the grieving process along with the characters of the show.  So, what shouldn't happen?  Exactly what did happen...another shock!  While rising from the loss of two beloved characters, we have to suffer more.  Why add another shock?  Well, to get our minds off of Mathew's death, of course.  This was a mistake, for sure; and one that could have been avoided if Julian Fellowes had been more trusting.  In turn, I believe he has lost the trust of many fans.Then too,  I think the development of characters is lacking, as they seem to be caught up in a whirlpool type of development which leaves the audience feeling a deja vu experience.  All of which adds up to Downton heading in the direction of, and allow me to coin a phrase from season one, "the slippery slope."I'll not desert the sinking ship, yet.  Perhaps it may still float.  Time will tell if this passenger stays aboard until season 4 docks.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really enjoy this series, but I just don't know why.  The Earl of Grantham (Big Daddy to us grubby colonists) is always wrong and insufferably snobby. The only members with a whit of social conscience is the former IRA terrorist and chauffeur, who only got where he is through marriage.The downstairs servants feel that they owe their lifelong allegiance to their "Masters", a sensation that I find mind-boggling.  I suppose you have to be from there to grasp that sort of predestination as acceptable - I kept feeling that here in the USA, that lifestyle would last about as  long as it takes to pack up and ease on down the road.I suppose that you have to take the historical perspective of Castles and serfs, then just say "That's the way it always was."We here in America grew up with the six-gun culture, and it marks us to this day.  I guess you are what you know.Having said that, this is a fine series, well acted, well filmed, and I would guess, well crafted of a time in history that is truly British.

reviewText: This round started out with O'Brien's abrupt, middle of the night departure (although I guess a hint of the possibility was given in the season 3 "special"). As of tonight I've watched PBS through part 6 and the rest on DVD- it all looks good. Some have complained about the writing or some of the story bits- you do get some surprises  but most viewers will think the Downton standard isn't slipping.Thomas Barrow is his old self again, Daisy & Ivy upset over Alfred, Bates turns out to be a most interesting character as a result of his time in prison (he's able to help Lord Grantham save the monarchy from embarrassment)- he and Anna have a violent storyline that may still be around next season. Mary still grieves over her loss of Matthew but ends up with 3 new suitors while Edith, poor girl, is still unlucky in love ( I'll be interested in seeing how that works out- that one will be difficult). Rose…is Rose, She never really tames down.I loved the new locations and vehicles used, even a street scene outside Buckingham Palace (very impressive effort though I'm sure it wasn't used for interior shots which still looked good).My biggest irritations are actually very minor- Lady Cora told Mrs. Patmore they were getting a new electric refrigerator (this was soon after the new electric mixer) - never saw /heard mention of it again. I'd have liked to have seen little Sybil and baby George more too-  they didn't get 10 minutes screen time between them the whole season!You do get the season 4 finale, "The London Season", with this set so don't go buying it separately.3 very good extras are included; "Downton Diaries", "The Making of" and "Meet the new cast" (some of them)- all worthwhile. I'm always suprised at how much a wig or hairstyle can change a persons appearance  and "behind the scenes bits are always good.If you could preorder 5th season this early I don't think you'd be taking too big a risk about viewing quality, 1-4 are that good.
summary: Started out in a surprising way, had some rough spots but ended very well

reviewText: I was worried that, at this point, the series would have gone stale.  It's so hard for a TV series to remain fresh year after year.  It's even harder when it's a series that is constrained by a certain time period.  If you think about it, the Abbey is somewhat of a prison, as most of the action takes place there.  They are also limited by what happened in history, rather than creating what is or what could be now.However, I was delighted to find that the series was still interesting and yes, fun.  And some of what I'm going to say may contain spoilers if you haven't watched the third season, and then I am going to discuss some of the plot from this season, so...SPOILER ALERT!Dame Maggie Smith was in her element and stole the show in every scene in which she participated.  She's just so GOOD in this role.  I admire actors who can take on a character who would be so easily hated and make them lovable (such as Alan Rickman with Snape in the Harry Potter movies.)  I loved how kind she was to Lady Edith and to Isobel.I also enjoyed Penelope Wilton's Isobel, as she beautifully took us through the grieving of her son.  And the interactions between Maggie Smith and her were quite wonderful.Michelle Dockery continues to amaze me with her restrained performance of Lady Mary.  Every trouble in the world is laid at her feet, and then people wonder why she can be hard as nails?  Can't imagine why!  She also did a great job in conveying her grief over the loss of Matthew.Finally, Joanne Froggat did a beautiful job in such a difficult performance.  The emotions she portrayed, the way they showed in her face, even the way she held herself...she's truly talented.If I had some complaints, it would be these (SPOILER ALERT):1.  Can there be no happiness for long for Mr. and Mrs. Bates?  First he's in jail, now she's raped.  I'm not saying it's not realistic - life can be very hard - but can they have SOME joy?2.  I'm dying to know Baxter's background.  I can't believe it was not revealed at all.3.  I couldn't remember what Daisy and Ivy were fighting about and honestly, it was just way too much for too long.4.  The whole Prince of Wales letter debacle was just, well, stupid.  Felt completely out of place.Still, great job by the whole cast and the storylines were mostly interesting and enjoyable.Highly recommend.

reviewText: There is no other show on television that plays with our emotions and moods as successfully as Downton Abbey. The classy story of the Grantham family and the parallel world of their servants will involve you, thrill you, make you cry, laugh, cringe, and repeatedly draw you back for more.Sure it's a wee bit soapy, and some scenes border on the melodramatic and the sentimental, but heck, who cares? That's the entire reason it succeeds; it's pure unadultered escapism entertainment. Well that and Downton Abbey's superb cast, led by the impeccableHugh Bonnevilleand the greatElizabeth McGovern, with the incomparableMaggie Smithgiving a fiery supporting lead, with Paul Giamatti, Brendan Coyle, and Michelle Dockery rounding out the talented main cast.Add to that excellent cinematography, rich costumes, beautiful sets and scenery, and authentic dialogue, and you have the makings of a fine show indeed. But when you add to THAT the brilliant human emotion, tangled relationships, colorful, sympathetic characters, wry humour, and a smart, fast-paced plot...you have the makings of near-perfection as only Masterpiece Theatre can make. This is Downton Abbey, and while it is not as epic as Game of Thrones, or as riveting as Breaking Bad or Person of Interest, Downton Abbey is like no other show on television. Your moods will rise and fall with the episodes and the fate of your favourite characters, be it Nurse O'Brien (who we all love to hate), or Edith Crawley (who we all hate to love) and every time you pop in the disc, you will be swept away for a wonderful evening of escapism to the lush mansion of Downton.Here's to much Downtonian delight in the future! 4.5 Stars!
summary: So what if it's soapy? It's Downton Abbey!

reviewText: It's really a shame the writers of Downton Abbey have ruined this classy production with violent rape.  In the first two episodes of season 4 it seems the writers have lost their muse and are producing a labored and rather boring story line, so they have to resort to the sordid rape of a favorite character in episode 3.  Add that to the deaths of two of Downton's  characters in Season 3, it's just too much and the joy is gone.  I think Downton's secret in the early seasons was to have just enough pathos to keep the plot interesting without becoming an American-style soap drenched with sleeze, creeps, blood and violence.  If you really want to enjoy the series, turn off the DVD player at the point where Mary presents their new baby to Matthew.  It's a real shame to see the high class of Downton trashed by sleeze.

reviewText: Downton Abbey is my alternate universe.  I adore the house, the characters, the story line, the clothes, the accents, the history, etc.  I heard "rumblings" when Season 4 was being shown in the U.K. that Season 4 was lacking in some way -- that it didn't stand up to previous seasons.  I reserved judgement until I watched the entire Season 4 DVD.  Season 4 did lack the terrible, wrenching tragedies of Season 3.  Downton Abbey devotees will know exactly of which I speak.  Yet, there was ample suspense, passion, and surprises to make this season one of my very favorites.  It was good to see Lady Mary coming out of her grief to begin to live again.  It was even better to see Lady Edith come front and center in this season.  She really came into her own.  Lady Mary's new love interests were diverting. The Dowager Countess was impressive and impeccable as always.  Lady Rose I've never cared for and that didn't change.  It was fascinating to see how the Great War brought about such change in Britain in all classes.  Now if only Season 5 would hurry.
summary: What joy to be home at Downton again!

reviewText: In spite of one totally and completely unnecessary plot development regarding Anna Bates (I would ask Julian Fellowes what the hell he was doing!!!???), this 4th season of Downton has been masterfully done!  We're all able to mourn Matthew and allow both Mary and Isobel time to heal and begin to live again.  Many people seem to dislike Rose but I like her quite a lot.  She has a lot to overcome with regard to the bitter relationship with her mother but it is my greatest hope that she will continue to grow and become a lovely person indeed.  She hasn't got Sybil's sweetness but she does have some of her spirit.  I love Tom more than ever and hope that season 5 will bring him good things indeed.  Violet is still a treat as is Cora.  I wish Thomas' redemption had continued more fully...and I hope Julian Fellowes will consider allowing Thomas to redeem himself.  All in all, this is a very satisfying series with only a few hiccups along the way.  And I do highly recommend it if you've loved Downton Abbey so far!
summary: a masterful return after Matthew's death

reviewText: I love this era.  Love the furnishings, the clothing, the sensibilities, the impeccable manners and the kindness shown. reviewText: There wasn't enough Thomas for me (I love his wickedness and the kind heart he keeps hidden) after the first show.  Other characters come and go;  I found Cora's brother confusing.  No sociopathic American playboy would change so drastically from the picture that's been painted of him.  Lord G is just annoying in the first few episodes, then thankfully charges off for a time.  Didn't like what happened to Anna, and Rose goes from overactingly annoying to being the bright spot.  Nice to see Mary thaw, Edith be stupid, and Mrs. Patmore, one of my favorite characters may be preparing to leave so Daisy can take over?  The two old ladies of Downton are great as usual.  The Xmas special IS in the UK version, despite what other reviewers say, so don't go by their misinformation.
summary: This season is setting up relationships, making changes, and kinda boring

reviewText: I thoroughly enjoyed Seasons 1, 2 & 3 of Downton Abbey. Then I saw the Journey to the Highlands and the first 3-4 episodes of Season Four. Are Julian Fellows and the series writers just taking their cues from the pulp writer's formula of "piling on more grief" or have they simply run out of creative ideas? Not only are they adding massive melodrama, but they are doing in a way such that two major characters are acting completely out of character. This is not how characters grow, this is how they grow stilted and die. About the only two interesting character lines left are Mary's and Tom's -- but these are only touched on sometimes, while the focus is on the melodramatic plot lines. I honestly don't think I will continue to watch the DVD set of Downton Abbey Season 4. It's too sub-standard.
summary: From Period Drama to This? - Skip Season Four (and the "Journey to the Highlands" Special as well)

reviewText: If I could rate just the actors, set and costume designers, I'd give Downton Abbey 5 stars. But what I can't stand about it, even though I perversely keep watching--apparently as an act of self-torture--is the writing. Why can't the writers for once really explore a character rather than write everyone as a caricature? If the characters were allowed to be real human beings, the contrived feeling of the storylines would disappear. The breaking down of class barriers in early 20th century Britain really is a fascinating subject: Why box it in with the 21st century's culture of idiocy and bad manners? What's really maddening is the pacing. It's as though the writers agreed: Every scene will be X minutes long and will be patched together in any ol' way with no continuity of emotion whatsoever between them. There is too much "Meanwhile upstairs at the Abbey ...," "Meanwhile downstairs at the Abbey ...," "Meanwhile back at the Dowager's house ..." or "Meanwhile back at Isabell's house ..." I had high hopes they had hit rock bottom with Dan Stevens leaving the show at the end of season 3 and so HAD to improve but, no, they just keep it up ... to wit:Edith and Michael: First off: Why? There's no chemistry between them. Edith is probably interested in being rescued from the Life of an Old Maid Aunt of the Manor. Michael's becoming a German citizen will certainly make life complicated when Hitler invades Poland but that's 17 years away. I want at least a hint of what his real motives are NOW. Is Edith still writing her column? As another reviewer suggests it would be fabulous if she were to move to London and immerse herself with the Lost Generation literati of the day.Anna and Bates: After episodes 3 and 4, I am soooo confused. Anna spent a good deal of season 3 devoting herself to Bates' defense on a murder charge because she was sure Bates is incapable of murder. But now she is convinced she cannot tell Bates what Gillingham's valet did to her because she's certain Bates would kill him.Mary and Lord Gillingham: When Lord Gillingham proposes in ep. 4, he tells her "You take as long as you need: two years, three ..." The next day he tells her he's gotta marry somebody, his fiance is waiting, so he'll be off now. Again, I am sooo confused.Tom Branson: Based on the shirtless scene from last season and his increasing moodiness, I take it he's supposed to be the brooding, heart-throb stud of this show. If that is the case, Allen Leech has been miscast.Barrow: Yes, his being a gay man forced to live in the closet is so frustrating he must occasionally take it out on his co-workers. I think I understood this from season 1. Can we move on?Cora Crawley aka Countess of Grantham: C'mon Julian Fellowes: Admit it. You write her as a little nave, a little impetuous because she's ... an AMERICAN.Daisy: Can anyone really be so dumb she doesn't realize how self-centered she is? I would expect a character as young as she is to develop, mature, become more self-aware. Being the first one in the scullery to use an electric mixer doesn't count.Rose: Rebellious teenage girl 1920s-style. Instead of an iPod with headphones she plays the gramophone in her bedroom as loud as she can. OMG, so annoying!Mrs. Patmore: The show's only relate-able character. But why is she a "Mrs"? I thought she was never married.

reviewText: No Spoilers. Why does everyone I know love Downton Abbey? When I ask the question, no one has a real answer.  For myself, I don't know either but I am enamored with it.  Season 4 introduces new characters and they are completely in sync with the existing cast.  It always amazes me that there are so many characters and so many stories held within each episode.  Season 4 does not disappoint.  We find ourselves in the thrust of the economic times and how the "House" is going to continue its survival.  Mary's spirit leads the House into times that "stirs the pot." I was hoping for a larger role for Tom this year but with so many characters, Tom's character continues to be stand-up-able. Edith, who previously has shown less characterization, has actually had more substance than previously and I believe that her story line will be extremely interesting for next season.  I really loved Season 4 but it seemed that it had difficulty in picking up the pace as well as creating the enthralling dimensionality that we have all enjoyed through the first 3 seasons.  Truth is that one of season 4's greatest accomplishments have been the continued growth of each cast member.  I really like the aspect of age.  We get to see Sibby and George through the generations to Grandmama.  The introduction of Americans in the script is so much fun and I so enjoy the quipping between the English and the Americans.  Also the bickering and challenges between Violet Crawley and Isobel Crawley is fun and really makes the quality and honesty of the family work some how.  I have been told that others just don't like TV about rich people.  I always chuckle because it simply isn't about the rich, it is simply about life in the 1920s.  Some of the most heart felt story lines are based on the staff.  I feel that the staff and the Crawleys are an inter-changeable family. Season 4 is Excellent and Fun to watch on Amazon Prime. It was interesting this season because I was able to seen the entire Season 4 in January.  Where on regular TV, it won't be completed until sometime in February. That was a great perk!
summary: Still Knocked Out From Season 3, Season 4 is a Respite
Title: N/A

reviewText: With a global audience of over 125 million, Downton Abbey Season 4 is probably the most anticipated show this year.  This number of followers is set to increase as Chinese State TV has, apparently, just started to broadcast it, although what the average Chinese television viewer will make of the antics of the Crawleys I shudder to think!  This time round we pick up six months on from the tragic end to the Series 3 Christmas Special.Downton has moved with the times, and, as usual, great care has been taken to make the setting, including all the small details, correct for the period.  Hence clothes and hair styles have changed and advances in technology, such as the telephone and even new fangled electric kitchen gadgets are evident.  The cast has all the significant characters who survived the last series, so Maggie Smith continues as the matriarch who dominates every scene she is in, and Shirley MacLaine makes a welcome reappearance after her all too brief involvement in the previous series.  Seeing her sparring with Maggie Smith must be one of the more memorable aspects of this show.  There are some new faces to look out for, one of whom is Kiri Te Kanawa, the New Zealand opera singer as well as a couple of other well known characters in cameo roles.More of the scenes this time round have been filmed on location in London.  Meanwhile at Downton itself, the antics and interaction of those `below stairs' continues to contribute some very interesting story lines and their trials and tribulations are, in many ways, one of the most interesting aspects of the show.  Above stairs initially Lady Mary is, understandably, rather subdued whilst Lady Edith really seems to be coming into her own having, perhaps, been somewhat overshadowed previously.  The producers have publicly promised no more deaths, at least for a while, but I will not be giving away any key parts of the plot here as I certainly do not want to spoil anyone's enjoyment!Downton Abbey has certainly continued to go from strength to strength and has confounded those critics who thought it would peter out after a couple of series.  If you enjoyed the previous seasons then Season 4 is unlikely to disappoint, and there is every sign that the show is set to continue.  I do not believe any announcement has been made about Season 5 yet but apparently some of the key figures have already signed contracts for it.  However, personally I would not be surprised to see it run up to the 1930s in due course.  I certainly hope so!For those of you interested in additional features this set includes 'The Making', The Downton Diaries and New Arrivals.Edit in January 2014 - Just to clarify following a number of comments on the review.  This review was written when Season 4 was released in the UK three months ago.  The set issued in the UK did not include the Christmas Special episode which is the finale as it was not aired until December 25th.  However, this North American issued set being released on Jan 28th certainly does include the Christmas Special (even though it is subtitled UK Edition!) ie this set as sold here does include the Christmas Special. Hope this makes sense.
summary: Downton Goes From Strength to Strength

reviewText: ***Spoilers Ahead*****I liked the first 3 seasons of DA and was saddened by the last minute of season 3.  Oh well life goes on.  I just watched season 4 and while entertaining it felt like it was missing something.  First the bad.  The reset button was hit for Thomas.  The end of series 3 was somewhat redemptive for him but by the end of episode 1 of season 4 he is the villain again.  Mary mourns for a couple of episodes but immediately has two (three?) suitors, none of whom is very interesting.  Tom Branson still mourns Sybil, and gets 2 relationships but again neither is interesting.  Lady Rose decides to have a relationship with a black band leader which could of been interesting but is such a underdeveloped part of the script it is unconvincing and felt tacked on.  I hated the Anna assault storyline.  If I wanted depravity I would turn into Law & Order Special Victims unit.What did I like?  Laura Carmichael as the ever suffering Lady Edith.  Her storyline was a little melodramatic and a little predictable but I found it was at least engaging.  Maggie Smith was wonderful as always as was Penelope Wilton as Isobel Crawley.  Kevin Doyle and Raquel Cassidy as Molseley and Baxter gave me underdogs to root for.  Even though I though Lady Rose's story was poorly executed, Lily James has good screen charisma.  Special mentions to Shirley MacLaine & Paul Giamatti for their work on the x-mas special.

reviewText: Even with all the rave reviews everywhere, I avoided this show until now, early 2014.  What could a bunch of stuffy upper-crusters from another time possibly have to offer?  Especially after the glorious ending to the inglorious Walter White on Breaking Bad, I was sure this one would be a snoozefest.  Well, I couldn't have been more wrong!From the very first frame, this show draws you into the rarefied world of the landed aristocracy of pre-WWI England, and darned if it doesn't just hook you!  While the elegant Crawley family maneuvers to preserve its social standing and financial future upstairs, a small army of assorted servants bustles about downstairs, keeping it all pristine and orderly. Every character is carefully drawn and superbly acted.  And despite all the conniving and spying and betrayal, you find yourself growing fond of these characters, waiting impatiently for the next episode to see what happens to them.It doesn't hurt that the castle where all this takes place is breathtakingly gorgeous.  Plus, there's Maggie Smith!  Hands down, the absolute BEST Snooty Old Bat, ever!  She's the most judgy, sarcastic, acid-tongued and hilarious matriarch on TV, and you'll love her!Go ahead, watch one episode.  I dare you to stop!
summary: I dare you to stop watching (you won't be able to)

reviewText: DISCLAIMER- once this review went live I noticed it was for the "original UK version" and I get mine from netflix and doubt I hadthat version, whatever is on that one.I enjoyed this, but the reason I  watch is to chill and get carried into a well done period drama.  I don't expect stark reality- in fact that is what is refreshing about these episodes- they don't try to be "raw" and "tough" like so many hangdog hollywood series. I am happy to see things roll along.I thought the central conceit of the series is people stuck in a bygone era, resisting change....well you can't fault season 4 for failing to represent that.  It doesn't really matter to me that nobody ages in ten years, or changes their personality, and the main way to "move on" is to die- I'm still chuffed to kick back and binge-watch the disc.Some things I noticed and enjoyed w/ this series- There was more humor, and  amusing rapartee .... although at one point there seemed to be a directors decision to have Mary and Edith talk as though they were captive in an underwater aquarium, talking slooow and low and  watery, (doubtful this had anything to do with conveying humor)  this was fairly quickly redirected and they reverted back to somewhat more normal conversations in an episode or two.I also noticed and liked that there was more of a focus on interactions and dramas with the staff, with longer, detailed segments devoted to the dynamics with their relationships and the various situations that affect their lives.  There were even gardeners this time- one wonders where they have been the past ten years. So yes, I will look forward to Season 5, and whatever else....
summary: FGS, it's just a tv show !

reviewText: Gosh I love this show!  It has many historical inaccuracies (such as the family treating the servants like close relatives) but to me that's what makes this show so wonderful.  The writers are able to merge the upstairs and the downstairs which gives the show a feeling of cohesiveness.  It's as if we're watching a show about a small town rather than a large house.  Barrow's humility at being allowed to return to Downton Abbey & even given a much better post is all gone and he is back to his nefarious ways. Mary is coming out of her extended period of mourning & beginning to realize that she is a hot commodity.  Bates & Anna are caught up in a web of lies & deceit that just may break them apart...and could end up with someone being hanged.  Cousin Rose is at her rebellious best.....Not the cliffhanger this season that we had in previous seasons, but all in all a stellar season - as usual.

reviewText: The origin of naming an English estate building "abbey" comes from Henry VIII giving confiscated Roman Catholic Church property (an abbey or a friary or a monastery) to English nobility (the aristocracy), as a reward for service to the king or, in the case of very powerful nobility, for simply supporting Henry in his "Great Matter", which was his quest to divorce Catherine of Aragon and marry Anne Boleyn, which lead to the separation of the English Catholic Church from the Church of Rome. The producers really should have sought out a structure that actually looks like an abbey (which Highclere Castle doesn't) or had Julian Fellows change the name of the estate. None of this makes a particle of difference, of course, to "Downton Abbey" which I absolutely love! I can't wait for Season 4!
summary: Highclere Castle Does Not Look Like Abbey

reviewText: The series, set in the fictional Yorkshire country estate of Downton Abbey, depicts the lives of the aristocratic Crawley family and their servants in the post-Edwardian era—with the great events in history having an effect on their lives and on the British social hierarchy. Such events depicted throughout the series include news of the sinking of the RMS Titanic in the first series; the outbreak of the First World War, the Spanish influenza pandemic, and the Marconi scandal in the second series; the interwar period and the formation of the Irish Free State in the third series; and the Teapot Dome scandal in the fourth series.  If you like British period dramas, Downton Abbey is for you

reviewText: I have been a huge fan of this series since day one.  It is with some trepidation I even write a review below five stars.  But it is because seasons 1 and 2 set the bar high.  Season 3, while generally very good, did not quite seem to reach the heights of 1 or 2.  With the 'ahem' occurrence at the end of season 3, the show has changed drastically.  Without spoilers, I would say that many of the characters have changed, and though many portray things realistically, I felt that the 'new' characters are not quite as interesting as they once were.A few events tend to grate on my nerves.  Most notably was the Earl taking part in a plot to re-steal a scandalous letter from a blackmailer.  Granted, he didn't want shame on his house, but the old Earl would not have taken part in something so dishonest, no matter the stakes.  Especially when he sends members of his family to con the hotel into letting them into the blackmailer's room!  Completely out of character and unrealistic.  The fallout of that scandal would have been worse than the original had they been caught!That is just one example.  But overall the show is still good.  I do dislike that the writers take a few story arcs and beat them to death.  It's much more drawn out than even the whole Bates murder trial event.Again - still good!  I just hope the melodrama gets toned down in future seasons.  And I know that Penelope Wilton and Maggie Smith were busy filming, but I also hope we get more of them in the next season than we did in this season.  And bonus points for Paul Giamatti.
summary: Starting to get a little too 'primetime soap opera-ish'
Title: N/A

reviewText: The sets are great.  Some of the acting is good.  The depiction of many aristocrats is believable in that they exhibit their naive ignorance of "real life".  Is this supposed to be a sociological look at the difference of classes, acceptance of people in an era when there was little acceptance of outsiders?  Is it supposed to be a fairy tale world of people getting along across the barriers of the crippling conventions of the British Empire?  Is it supposed to imply that the favored rich of that world have big hearts and are just ordinary folk who can accept the chauffeur with no demur?  To show how the Americans appeared to underwrite many of the great houses of Britain but were generally still looked down upon for their differences?  Anthony Trollope may have been able to do justice to this group of people, but I think the story as it is goes nowhere.With all real soap operas too many characters get into the stew as they are introduced to keep the story going,  and then there isn't time to develop anything very deeply.  Too many cameo parts, and no cohesive story.  The last episode was the worst of all, leaving everything up in the air with no resolutions.  Julian Fellowes just seems unable to let go of all this panorama of people moving around, dancing, being presented at court and almost always punctuated by that MUSIC.  Who wrote that theme song?We are subjected to that putrid music constantly as well as all these unlikely relationships.  Granted there are some stand-out characters such as Maggie Smith and some of the other women, but compare it to the old Upstairs Downstairs where every episode really had some sort of genuine social or political issue and the class thing was so much more in the open?  Or Brideshead Revisited for its ambience.  Both of those works had a beginning middle and end and both of them were well written.I vote no on Downton Abbey.  I really hoped it would improve, that there would be some actual depth in the story, that something would happen--- but it just floated out on that never ending theme song of sawing violins.
summary: Downton Abbey is a Dopey soap opera set in a phony world accompanied by sawing violins

reviewText: For those who don't just swoon over something out of habit, I think most actual viewers will acknowledge (with regret) that something is definitely off about the opening episode(s) of DA's Season 4.  To me, the first hour was just tedious with a now very unsympathetic Mary, who actually seems more disgruntled than grieving.  Her self-absorption carries a bitter bite and less interest than usual in anyone but herself, including her child.  However, the second hour picked up, along with Mary's spirits.Overall though, that unmistakable vital edge we have become accustomed to with DA was sorely lacking, rendering the whole rather flat, acting included.  The scenes in the downstairs area particularly palled for the first time, especially some in the kitchen.  Same great people, but the fire is missing. Even Maggie Smith's parts were lackluster.  There's a point where the best actors cannot overcome trite dialog and boring recycles of old themes.I had understood formerly that Julian Fellowes is involved in at least one other large project, and perhaps that explains what seems a lack of due diligence to this one.  Even with that, he seems to be diminishing his main characters in stature and depth while escalating devious and underhanded elements. His current presentation appears to be going in the way of his "Gosford Park," where everyone was foibled - and worse.Whatever it is, overall and in several key areas like the writing, directing and now some of the acting, unless this one picks up with continuing episodes, it is destined to end in a fizzle, a shadow of its former self.Regardless, I will cherish my first two seasons DVDs as they will always carry the vibrant pulse and excellence that set Downton Abbey apart.
summary: Review of Opening Night's Program - US Viewing

reviewText: The fourth season of Downton Abbey, like the others before it, is superbly well written and acted.  Each episode is built around some form of suspense and intrigue, and as the family and their retainers enter the 1920s the old ways of life begin to crumble.  As always there are characters to love, to hate and to pity.  Maggie Smith is brilliant in her portrayal of a 19th century grand dame with a secretly modern outlook.  We miss the actors who had to be 'killed off' because they couldn't continue with the series, but their demise is skillfully woven into the ongoing story through new drama and development.  The overall theme has been attempted before with some measure of success - for example To The Manor Born and You Rang My Lord? - but nowhere as cleverly and realistically as Downton Abbey.

reviewText: Downton came to my attention half way through the first season; and I was thrilled to find a series which actually lived up to the press hype.I've purchased the series through Amazon Prime; and have yet to be disappointed w/ their service; I wish the same could be said of the fourth season.It's as though Mr. Fellowes has spent far too much time surfing the average, or below average American Drama line-up searching for plot lines, only to fail miserably.I did away w/ the Cable/Dish; so I could control my viewing, instead of opting for the best of a bad lot, only to have it visited upon me here as well. I suppose it’s the plague of people like Mr. Fellowes; that when ratings begin to drop, their knee-jerk reaction is to revert to the redundancy of tired scenarios while throwing in violence, making sure it’s once again targeted towards women. I fear that before the series ends he has insured that Anna, the moral compass of the story, will sadly find herself in the role of widow.As was stated in another review; there are so many other characters w/ the potential for great story lines if only the time and interest were still there to bring them to fruition.

reviewText: This is an excellent series that gives an interesting insight into the early 20th century, and not only among the "upper" class but among those less privileged and less affluent. It's far better, in my mind, than Upstairs Downstairs, which was a very fine series. I've read criticism of this fourth season that it's getting stale and needs a new writer, but I don't agree. Julian Fellows has written wonderful dialog (giving Maggie Smith some of his best), and the way he develops his story line is interesting, engaging and convincing. Of course, having superior actors who perform at their best, along with great locations, vehicles and other properties adds a great deal. My wife and I, along with many friends, are among the millions of followers who find this series is just our cup of tea.

reviewText: I was pleased to see some of the writing that was so that had me hooked in seasons 2 and 3 towards the end of season 4. It didn't have the zest, intrigue or  the sassy dialogue that was seasons 2 and 3 had so richly intertwined throughout those seasons.It seems that Edith, Rose and Tom Branson (Sybil's widowed husband) will continue to have a tendency to keep getting into trouble.It will also be interesting to see how things develop with Mary and her current two suitors. Each one of the suitors has their own merits.I was very disappointed in the casting of Cora's brother when they went with Paul Giamatti. I have seen him portray a villain very well but he was a poor choice for the role of someone who is supposed to be a well known playboy. The character was also poorly written because he had no social graces at all. They could have made a much better choice for this role in terms of writing and casting.I enjoyed the little storyline for Daisy and the possibility of romance for Mr Carson.Episode 9 has me anxious to see the new developments for the upcoming season 5. It's a shame that it will take nearly another year before we can see it in the United States. (sigh)

reviewText: I simply do not care what any critics have to say - yes, it's rather soapy, contains anachronisms, a shifting cast and abrupt departures - but by god, I just flat out love this series.  There is something compelling about the order and civility of it.  Fellowes has created wonderful characters that you love to love and hate - Thomas...grrrr!It's a staple of Sunday evening, and one of the few shows that my partner and I agree on completely.  She'd get rid of me before she gave up DA.So my advice: relax, turn off the critical faculties and enjoy every moment.The civility of it.  The decency of individuals.  There's no hugging but a touch means the world and a handshake seals the deal.There is something to be said for  some of the series' old-fashioned virtues; and yes, I understand the underside as regards class, race, gender, and religion (Lord Grantham's reflections on the Catholic faith are delightfully horrid).But our time could use a bit of the manners on display here.
summary: Just one more glowing review - a tribute to the virtues of a different time and reminder of why now is "better"

reviewText: The continuation of Julian Fellowes’ masterpiece has been downgraded to tragic mediocrity.  His opening chapters have served as quick explanations for the death of Matthew, the loss of O'Brien, the treachery of Thomas, the blindness of Cora, and the ineptness of Robert.  It has also reached into the private cubbies of the faithful viewers to crush their carefully created perceptions and beliefs about those remaining characters that have so boldly taken up residence in our hearts.  Fellowes has torn us from that intangible fabric that I describe as character continuity.  Without it, the viewer becomes lost in an aimless sea of change.  What made Downton Abbey different was the viewer’s ability to count on the responses of the remaining characters to reasonable crisis.  The launch of season 4 has destroyed that expectation.  Fellowes failed to fully take us, the fans, into his many considerations as he dealt with the troublesome issues of cast mutiny and other more mundane production issues.  The result is mediocrity, and in my opinion, unrecoverable fan alienation.  That is not to say the show will fail, on the contrary, I think it will succeed, but with a very different viewer base.  Those of us who have made it a viewing hit have been "kicked to the curb".  I suppose that is the way of things, but I cannot in good conscience let such a flagrant disregard for the feelings of those who "brung you to the dance" go without a protesting word.The launch of season 4 indicates that Fellowes has repositioned the series.  It is no longer in the category of a masterpiece classic, but in the genre of a soap opera styled period tragedy.  It has lost the spark of differentiation that pushed it to masterpiece status and has been relegated to idiotic inconsistencies and unbelievable situations.  Come on Julian… you can do better than that!Lady Rose MacClare has come to live at Downton Abbey.  She is a wild child with poor judgment.  She is a liar and a seeker of experiences below her station.  She is a 1920's "flapper" who has had an affair with a married man in London and looks for excitement in the most dangerous of places.  There is no reason whatsoever for anyone at Downton to trust her.  She prepared an ad to find a ladies maid for Cora, and placed it in a shop window in town.  She collected the responses and presented them to Cora.  Why?  Cora did not ask her to do this nor did she give Rose permission to solicit on her behalf.  There is no reason for Rose to take it upon herself to place the advertisement.  Cora on the other hand is an American who is self sufficient and used to doing things for herself.  Edna Braithwaite applies along with others, but Rose pushes Cora to accept Edna.  Rose has no prior known relationship with Edna, therefore, no good reason to push for her acceptance by Cora.  During the interview, Cora finds out that Edna once worked at Downton, but left with a good reference from Mrs. Hughes.  Cora is aware of the politics that surrounds the management of subordinates.  She knows that giving a good reference to a terminating employee is not always evidence of good behavior on that job.  However, she does not consult Mrs. Hughes to determine the facts of the termination, but accepts the recommendation of Rose.  This situation doesn't pass the smell test.  In the past, Cora has proven that she is level headed, and capable.  She is not stupid.  Why would she accept an applicant without confirming the circumstances of the termination with her long term employee, Mrs. Hughes? This situation is unbelievable and highly insulting to the American character of Cora.  In other words, American women ain't that stupid!Edna Braithwaite is a character with vindictive and selfish purpose.  Upon learning of Branson's circumstances and his rise to aristocratic station, she has set out to bring him down or join the ranks of aristocracy herself through her manipulated bond with him.  It is unclear, at this juncture, which direction she intends to pursue.  She has shown her willingness to ignore the protocols of her station in the household and snub some minor advice from Anna about Thomas.  She does not show great commitment to the job of Ladies Maid for Cora and demonstrates a propensity to defy the orders of Mrs. Hughes.  Thomas makes overtures to Edna and she accepts his friendship.  When she negligently damages a garment of Cora's, Thomas assists by instructing her not to admit guilt and he puts the blame for the damage onto Anna.  Anna has been a trusted employee for years.  She has never demonstrated behavior that would cause Cora to question her trust. However, in this unbelievable situation, Cora accepts the explanation of Thomas because of his newly acquired status of trust which he gained through “Nannygate”, and does not ask Anna for an explanation about the damaged garment.  The American woman whose financial fortune saved Downton Abbey is being portrayed as an easily manipulated idiot.A nanny is employed to care for the two grand children of Cora and Robert; Tom Branson's daughter, and Matthew Crawley's son.  She isolates the children from most of the family and refuses to take orders from Thomas, the "Under Butler".  Thomas, for the wrong reasons, rightfully informs Cora that the nanny is not all she is cracked up to be.  Cora eavesdrops on her and discovers she is being cruel to her first grandchild, the former chauffer's (Tom Branson’s) daughter.  Cora immediately dismisses her.  On the surface, this situation appears appropriate.  Thomas appears to be a Good Samaritan.  Beneath the surface, he appears to be vindictively attacking the nanny for failing to recognize his authority as "Under Butler".A package addressed to Mary arrives.  It contains the personal effects of Matthew.  Mrs. Hughes convinces Carson that the contents should be inspected for items that may cause Mary additional grief.  Carson decides that Robert should be given that dubious honor.  The ethics grow increasingly fowl with this decision.  Do Mrs. Hughes, Carson, and subsequently, Robert think they should withhold, hide, or destroy some item(s) that rightfully belong to a grieving widow in some poorly reasoned desire to mitigate her grief?  Mary has proven over the last three (3) seasons that she has the ability to handle her own affairs.  A letter is found by Robert in Matthew’s personal effects that clearly outline his wishes regarding the disposition of his estate.  It is clear that this is a holographic will.  Robert shares it with the Dowager who tells him that it must be presented to Mary, its rightful owner.  Mary rightfully shows displeasure with her father for going through her husband's effects and sharing the contents of the letter with her grandmother.  Robert claims the letter is not a will and must be sent to the family attorney to determine its validity and authority.  The family lawyer confirms the status of the holographic will and Mary is recognized as 50% owner of Downton Abbey.  The lack of ethics displayed by Mrs. Hughes, Carson, and Robert are a slap in the face of British aristocratic culture for that era.Rose, the wild child convinces Anna to chaperone her on a visit to London.  They go to a rough and ready bar where a fight breaks out between two men who want her attentions on the dance floor.  When they return to Downton Abbey, one of the two men call on her thinking she is a ladies maid.  Anna assists her in the deception by helping her dress in maid's attire.  Rose greets the young man and lies to him regarding her status.  She tells him she is involved with another man, but passionately kisses the visiting man goodbye.  She tells the first footman, Jimmy Kent, who just happened to be in the rough and ready bar in London at the time of the fight, and helped she and Anna escape, to go along with her lies.  Julian!!  What are you thinking?  Is everyone at Downton corrupt?  What's going on here?Branson begins to feel uneasy with his new status.  He tells Edna Braithwaite and she quickly responds.  This situation was anticipated when Edna was hired by Cora.  The replacement of O'Brien with Edna Braithwaite was not properly developed.  However, this situation can be corrected.Lord Gillingham arrives for a party with his valet, Mr. Green.  The valet waits for an opportunity to be alone with Anna, the only married woman on the staff.  He beats and rapes her.  Anna hides in Mrs. Hughes' quarters.  Mrs. Hughes arrives to find Anna beaten, bloodied, and raped.  Mrs. Hughes wants to call in help.  She wants to call in Dr. Clarkson, but Anna demands that she not reveal to anyone what has happened to her.  She is afraid that her husband, Bates will kill the jackal and go back to prison for murder.  Mrs. Hughes complies.  Is Anna to become pregnant with a rapists child and hide the ancestry of the child from her husband?  Will she have a child and put it up for adoption?  Will she have an abortion?  Will she lose Bates for failing to trust him as a man and husband?  Is Anna the latest of many victims of this rapist?  Will rapist Green return or try to blackmail Anna?  This occurrence tipped the scales for me.  Downton Abbey is no longer a masterpiece classic, it is a soap opera styled period tragedy that does not challenge the viewer in a modestly intellectual way, but shocks and tramples the established character traits of its remaining cast.I am so disappointed in the first three installments of Season 4, that I am giving thought to boycotting the remainder of the season.  I probably won't, but I am giving it some thought.  In the first three seasons, Thomas and O'Brien were the ethically challenged culprits.  In Season 4, just about every main character is an antagonist.  Who can we the viewers trust to have integrity?  Now when I see the beautiful Highclere Castle, it does not bring about feelings of warmth, security, and respectability as it has in times gone by.  It now looks like a house of horrors filled with death, debauchery, rape, and personal ruin.  When I want to endure that kind of tragedy and pathos, I will turn to Shakespeare… or Mickey Spillane.

reviewText: Having waited to watch Season 4 of Downton Abbey as it aired on PBS, and then going back to re-watch immediately after on blu-ray, I am struck by how much was in this season.  The costumes and acting and script is, of course, still brilliant and one of the best things on tv, IMHO.  Plus, how can you go wrong with the backdrop of Downton with its incredible rooms and the estate.  No matter that, this season, we spend some time in London, the estate and the house remain part and parcel of this show.The stories both upstairs and downstairs still draw us in, as do the characters.  We love them.  We hate them.  There is romance and intrigue and discovery and wonder.  What more can you want in a drama?  In addition, the modern world keeps coming into Downtown--as we've moved from the introduction of the telephone and electrity in earlier seasons to sewing machines, mixers, and even talk of a refrigerator!  Its interesting to see what we take for granted these days as something strange and new and even a bit frightening.Some spoilers below.Very much, Season 4 is about love and loss.  Not just the obvious about Mary mourning the tragic loss of her husband, Matthew, as she lingers in the beginning between life and death.  But we all know her strength, even if she seems to have lost sight of it.  I also enjoyed the scene where the Dowager talked to Mary about making a choice over coming out of her loss, and also how she told off her son, Robert, when he would protect Mary from everything, even herself.  Its also good to see so many men chasing after Mary--she well deserves it!Edith also faces love and loss and having to make a hard decision when it comes to her own love, Michael Gregson, and I've gone from disliking Edith as a character to feeling sorry for her and even admiring her for her own strength.  She's really come into her own in this season.  Her big choice, however, I suspect will come back to haunt her in Season 5 perhaps?Branson is still also in mourning, not just for his wife but for his life.  He seems more unsure in this season, as if the fire had gone out of him.  Yes, he meets a new interest, but I'm still waiting for him to become the firebrand we knew from previous seasons...if only a bit more down to earth.  I really felt his story was one of the low points of the season, as I honestly don't care as much about him as I used to.  The other plot line I don't care for is Rose.  She just seems spoiled and annoying most of the time and we all know her romance with the bandsinger would come to nothing in the end.  I wish they would get Branson back to being himself again and figure out what to do with Rose besides trot her out to dance and play music and flirt all of the time.Downstairs, there is the triangle of unrequited love with Daisy and Ivy and Alfred, which I thought they resolved in a very grown-up fashion.  There is also the question of what does Thomas hold over Cora's new maid?  Not to forget, the darkest plotline in this season--the brutal attack on Anna.  This was very hard to watch and really brought home some of the issues of being a woman in the 1920's.  When her husband finally found out and comforted her, it made me cry.  As for Mr Bates--did he or didn't he?  The Anna-Bates storyline remains one of the best in the show, shrouded as it is in hardship and pain over which the power of their love for each other wins through.The final episode went from the palace to the seaside and, I must admit, watching our dour butler wading is well worth waiting a whole season for...Overall, this is a great season and it remains a great show.  I can't wait for Season 5!
summary: Season 4 and I Still Love It

reviewText: British viewers have already viewed Season 4, or The fourth series, as we would say over here, and in my humble opinion it's the best one yet.  Julian Fellowes writes brilliant conversation pieces with brilliantly conceived characters.  However, his plots seem a bit improbable at times.  The character, 'Matthew' had to be written out because the actor hungered for greener pastures thereby giving Fellowes the headache of how to remove him from the show permanently halfway through his storyline without destabilising the whole season's plot.As for the reviews and previews submitted so far, there appears to be a dividing line between those who hunger for more action, and those who feel they have had rather too much of it already.  This stretches our credulity at times, and  those who are looking forward to a little more fun without any major disasters removing yet more of our favourite characters, will have much to celebrate in Season 4.  Meanwhile, we await this year's Christmas Special with bated breath.

reviewText: Once again, as in Upstairs..., the focus is on the abrupt challenges to the life-style of the privileged in pre-war (WW1) England. Through brilliant character development, we participate in the effect of the war on the privileged classes' sense of entitlement. We experience, along with the characters, the shock of such life altering changes as the womens's right to vote movement, dating between the races, the breakdown of the classes, and defiance of parental authority. Some are able to adjust, others stand firm. The present age is experiencing a similar dichotomy in the digital revolution. Be sure to watch only the UK version to avoid cuts made in the American version, probably not because of content but for differing time structure allotments.  Addictive.
summary: Best Series on English Royalty in transition since Upstairs Downstairs

reviewText: I know there's been a lot of negatively surrounding season 4 of Downton, but if you're a fan, don't give up. Of course we miss Sybil and Matthew, but since the actors chose to leave, there's nothing to be done about it. I believe that the writers did a great job considering that they had to rewrite characters' lives. I do like the addition of what Violet calls "Mary's men." Sure, it's a little distasteful that she has three men hanging from the fishing line, but instead of thinking of it that way, enjoy them. The actors do a wonderful job, they're all so handsome, and their characters really do add a nice element to the story (even though we still miss Matthew). My main complaint is what they're doing with Tom Branson (Sybil's husband). Sure, he still misses his wife, and he's lonely, but do they really have to pair up such a great guy with those horrid women. Please, please say that Miss Bunting won't return because I can't stand her character. Rose's childish antics can't compare with Sybil's free spirit, but I'm glad they made her a bit different rather than trying to "create" another personality like Sybil's. She brings a little spunk to the show. Mary is the "cold fish," but she's still one of my favorites, and has some great one-liners. Not as great as Violets, but still worth a laugh.Anyway, rant over. I really do adore this show, and I look forward to season 5. All in all, I believe they're doing a great job considering all the changes.

reviewText: What hasn't been said in praise of this series?  They have produced a series that teaches the huge shift in world economics and social change that took place a hundred years ago.  For many folks, it's just very entertaining, but the writers have managed to sneak in the very importance and essence of the intricate social changes that still effect us all today.PBS did a special on Highclere Castle, the actual site of Downton Abbey.  It is still occupied by an Earl & his wife.  There is a butler, two chefs, a total staff of about twenty.  It is still surviving, but the annual costs run over a million pounds a year, and the Downton Abbey filming is a big help in that regard.  I found that show on another provider's menu - Netflocks, or something like that.  Highclere is also a popular tourist attraction, a few thousand acres are now dedicated to productive farming, and high end bird hunting is also a bread winner for the estate.Probably like you, I hope the series continues on for many more seasons.  I love it when education can be so entertaining.

reviewText: It is an all captivating and nonstop adventure. The characters are fully developed and constantly true to part. A bygone era meticulously depicted allows one to visit an elegant time period. It is an intelligent show full of period memorabilia adding to a charm totally lost today. The acting is superb. The areas used for filming are breathtaking in opulence, meticulous in every detail of life as it was in various segments of society in that part of the world.Foremost it is refreshingly British. This is a show which will not compromise its quest for movie making perfection in our time when computer generated images are a norm and "Good enough" IS good enough.A MUST ADD HERE:After three thousand five stars l had to go check on why oh why, one hundred reviewers gave it one star. As l thought, negative opinions must surface, especially when faced with overwhelming positives. The thing here which is hilarious is, all these reviewers with one star who claim to have wished a character had remained or another had...whatever, the point? ....the point, they all had to watch it throughout first. reviewText: I looked forward to season four with great anticipation and it was delivered on the first day of distribution.  My husband and I settled down to watch the entire season and I must admit that I was disappointed.  Season four seemed to lack the excitement and the anticipation of exciting things ahead.  It seemed to be more a series of short events strung together.  It moved quickly from scene to scene that things hardly had a chance to develop.  I actually fell asleep in my chair during Part 9 and missed part of what was happening (or not happening).  I can't believe that I actually fell asleep during Downton Abbey!  That would have been impossible in the previous seasons.  There just wasn't much excitement in this series.  Rose does nothing for me.  Of course I will watch season five when it comes out (and I may even watch  part nine of this season that I slept through again to see if I missed anything of real interest).  But something was lacking.  It was slow moving.  You can never dislike Downton Abbey, but I do have to say that this season I was disappointed and let down by my favorite show.
summary: Disappointed in season four of Downton Abbey

reviewText: With the shocking conclusion to Season 3, many Downton Abbey aficionados wondered whither, and whether, the series could go on.  Season 4 demonstrates that there can indeed be life "after Matthew" for the noble Earl and Countess of Grantham, their daughters, son-in-law, grandchildren, mother, and ever loyal staff.It's the 1920s, and life is really getting back to "normal" again at Downton Abbey after the upsets of World War I.  Lord Grantham continues to deal with the changing face of the world, assisted now by the surprisingly able Lady Mary, his eldest daughter who is now the mother of his heir.  His son-in-law Tom Branson and his younger daughter Lady Edith continue to search for roles of their own.  There's a new young lady in the house now, Lady Rose, a cousin of the Granthams who is making her London debut (her presentation at Buckingham Palace is marvelous).  Meanwhile, below stairs the servants loyally keep the house moving smoothly most of the time, barring the occasional catastrophe here and there.I enjoyed Season 4, though in truth I must say that I find Downton wearing a little ragged around the edges.  The original concept was so quintessentially Edwardian that it doesn't seem to quite fit into the Jazz Age, though Julian Fellowes and his writing team continue to do a masterful job.  As always, it's the wonderful cast that makes the series worth watching, especially Maggie Smith, Penelope Wilton, Michele Dockery, and Jim Carter.
summary: The Crawleys And Their Staff Soldier On

reviewText: The angle of this particular knock-off of Pride and Prejudice is that the Bennet sisters take on the social status and manners of the Bingleys.  The character who most resembles the Liza we remember is Matthew, in a thoroughly modern gender reversal.  Don't fear for Mr. Darcy's character, however; successors abound.Alternatively, Downton Abbey may of course be viewed as an Upstairs, Downstairs knock-off, with Matthew and Lady Mary acting out the back-story of Richard Bellamy and Lady Marjorie.  In place of Jean Marsh's relatively spare, grown-up world of London and a professionally active head of household, Downton Abbey adopts as its principal character the consumer values of the house itself, with its decor, furnishings, table settings, and grounds (and of course the costumes and hair styles).  Perhaps it's a case of "Upstairs, Downstairs Meets The Age of Innocence."  The production values are obviously very high.In any case, what's really new is that the action of Downton Abbey comprises about 13 -- or is it 30? -- sub-plots running simultaneously.  The cutting is fast and furious, as if it needs to get each scene in before the next tweet hits the audience's smart phone.One aspect that has been a little surprising to me is that, for a work with an atmosphere that is predominantly humane, the bodies do pile up, don't they?  I don't think they're trying to be Shakespearian; it's just that no one has tenure any more -- everyone's an adjunct.Downton's realization that Ireland exists ensures its fourth star.
summary: Jane Austen Meets Upstairs, Downstairs and Contracts ADD

reviewText: I have been such a huge fan of Downton Abbey.  This story is so important to me as a member of the Spencer family and relation to the current Earl of Spencer (also sharing the same full name as my father) at the family estate in Althrop.Yet after the fabulous season 3, and cliff hanger, season 4 was such a let down. Instead of revealing plot for those who have not seen season 4.. All I will say is that this season the plot will center around two key events. One surrounding Anna Bates (chamber maid) married to John Bates (butler/valet)... which after the sadness, drama of previous seasons of following these two characters.. was the plot twist really realistic or necessary?  The other concerns lady EdithHowever some of the great characters are just not even developed in season 4. BOO!  Personally I was shocked that the incredible acting of Rob James Collier as Thomas Barrows was not showcased after season 3. Meaning after the incident between Thomas and Jimmy, and Thomas profound lonliness and determination to up in class ranks, that they did not develop a plot around him. Was this because O'brien left the show?  Which was also awful. She was essential to the plot.  So sad.The other characters of Daisy, Mrs. Pattmore etc. are hardly developed this season.  And the love interest of Jack Ross for Lady Rose is sort of funny and odd choice for plot... not to mention his vocal styling is completely wrong for the period. AKA mediocre.Also Kiri Te Kanawa as Nellie Melba? REALLY? pleassssssse. LOL  Not to mention Nellie Melba would have never sung in a private home, not to mention the repertoire choice was mediocre.How about Mary's development? WOW not well thought out.  Such a let down!! A bit insulted after the great writing from the previous 3 seasons!.  Fans deserve better.  It feels like this was slapped together quickly.The final Xmas episode is sort laughable too with the plot at Buckingham Palace. It would have been much more interesting to have filmed in NYC during the jazz age. esp with more involvement from Shirley MacClaine who does a splendid job as usual.Luke warm rating.J. R. is the author of:Lady Liberty: The Definitive Julie London Handbook
summary: Season 4 is a let down like a scone sitting out too long with luke warm Earl Grey tea

reviewText: The series is still wonderful, and I will continue to watch it (for a while longer, at least), but with Matthew and O'Brien gone it just doesn't have the same appeal to me.  Anna getting raped was very disturbing, and I'm not sure it was a good move when there are other directions the show could have gone in to create a dramatic situation. I understand rape is unfortunately  a fact of life, but I was not happy it was included in Downton Abbey, especially in that day and age when help for a rape victim was mediocre, at best. Also, I found myself rolling my eyes in disbelief when Carson's old buddy shows up again and moves in with Isobel because Mrs. Hughes takes it upon herself to befriend him and orchestrate his salvation. Really? Cora's one-dimensional character is beginning to grate on my nerves. For example, when Branson's seducer, the former house maid Edna returns, gullible Cora hires her on the spot as her lady's maid, based upon the fact she had been employed by Downton previously for about three days before she was bounced by Mrs.Hughes. Edna has little if any experience as a lady's maid and was the only applicant, but 18 year old Rose likes her and encourages Cora to give her a try. Now there's a reliable source when considering who to hire as your closest personal employee! However, Mrs. Hughes, Carson, and Branson agree they simply can't tell poor Cora about Edna's inappropriate behavior toward Branson when she worked in the house before, because Mrs. Hughes did write her a good reference when she left (at Branson's request). They fear if they told gentle Cora the truth about Edna, Her Ladyship might come down with the "vapors" and need a smelling salt, or something! Please!  Robert, although I do like him basically, can be too much of a snobby prig for words...has he totally forgotten he would have lost Downton because of his really bad investment if Matthew hadn't come to the rescue?  Now at times he doesn't have the insight, humility, or willingness to listen to others who have excellent suggestions on how to profitably run the estate.  Mary and the Dowager Countess are the only interesting and multifaceted characters left, in large part because of their superb acting and excellent writers. I also think Isobel adds a lot to the show with her terrific acting skills and interactions with the Dowager Countess.  I also love Daisy, and hope they build some story lines around her other than her mooning over Alfred. Thomas is always terrific fun to watch, as his mischievous ploys downstairs and upstairs are usually wickedly delicious. If Mary and her British grandmother go the show is doomed. I love Shirley MacLaine, but her stiff portrayal of Cora's mother is dull and adds nothing. In my opinion, continuing with the deeper progression into Edith's struggles, relationships, and activities is the way to proceed with this character. I enjoy watching this great actress work, and more of her would be most welcome. Some of the most captivating episodes to come will hopefully revolve around who Mary becomes romantically involved with...that's worth continuing to tune in for at least a while longer. I realize this series takes place in a different place, time, and social class than 21st century America, and overall I feel it is a wonderfully researched, written, and acted series that I have enjoyed tremendously.  In conclusion, I believe the quality and direction of the first four episodes I've watched of Season Four do not rise to the level of the first three seasons.  However, I suppose I'm still mourning the loss of Matthew, Lady Sybil, and the complex O'Brien. I truly hope Season Four will "settle in," and the compass of excellence will be regained.
summary: NOT AS GOOD AS PREVIOUS SEASONS, BUT HOPING IT WILL GET BETTER
Title: N/A

reviewText: My wife and I loved Downton Abbey from the first episode. To an extent, we still think very highly of it.But we watched the first two episodes of Season 4 last night and, when they ended, heaved a big "meh."There are a number of problems with Season 4 of Downton Abbey:CAUTION: MIGHT BE SPOILERS AHEAD!1. Thomas is still there, and still a colossal pain in the ass. Despite being one of the most despicable people at Downton Abbey, nearly universally disliked by every other character, Thomas is still employed at D.A.2. Now that Miss O'Brien is gone (she left in the middle of the night without telling anyone), Cora Crawley needs a new Lady's Maid. Enter Edna, who more or less tricks her way back into D.A. by answering an ad to be Miss O'Brien's replacement. The character was without scruples when we last saw her; she's not improved now, and quickly forms an alliance with Thomas.3. So, once again, Thomas is paired with a woman - this time Edna - to wreck havoc on the other servants at D.A.4. The problem with that is two-fold: (a) the person they chose to stab in the back is Anna. Anna! The sweetest, most compassionate and kind member of the staff; and (b) the Earl and Countess of Grantham actually believe Thomas and Edna when they speak ill of Anna. Cora Crawley, apparently not the sharpest crayon in the box, always took the side of Miss O'Brien, too. But now she's taking the side of a brand new Lady's Maid against Anna! How can that be? Can Cora and Robert Crawley really be that bad a judge of character? When Robert confronted Bates to tell him to keep Anna in check, my wife and I looked at each other and shook our heads. Would Robert have done that? Does he not know what kind of people Bates and Anna are?5. The fact that we now have nearly the same configuration of characters we did in Season 1, with the nearly the same conflict, tells me that Julian Fellowes is out of ideas. Now he's just recycling what came before, only setting it in a new year (1922, if I recall the super on the screen correctly). Characters who do not change, who remain the same, are really bad, two-dimensional characters. Cora Crawley hasn't changed. She's still a dimwit. Thomas hasn't changed. He's still a manipulating scuzz ball. Bates and Anna are still the moral center of Downton Abbey. But now that Thomas and Edna are set on attacking them, I'm afraid we're ready to stop watching.We enjoyed Season 1-3 and watched them religiously. A few of them made us cry. We really got into the characters and the stories.But something feels really off about Season 4. Or maybe something feels precisely on. Everyone is exactly the same. And if all Julian is going to do is recycle the same conflicts (usually with Thomas and his female cohort), then we've got better things to do with our time.
summary: Plots Getting Tired, Characters Becoming Caricatures

reviewText: Tragedy, intrigue, romance, scandal, and the old lord clearly stating he is a monarchist while defending his social class.  Great gravy, this was a good season.  Granny is better than ever.  We are watching her age and move closer to the end, and this actress remains the creme de la creme of the show.  Her patience with so many people beneath her social class clamoring to give her attention and a turn around the ballroom is amazing. Mary's class consciousness makes me want to send her to the House of Lords, but oh not in her day.  It is hard to believe that Robert and Cora would overlook the moody illegitimate pregnancy of one of their daughters.  They all hang out together too often to not miss her for four months and note that she couldn't care less about Swiss French.  Perhaps George will one day stumble over his half sister tending a pig pen, and look out for sparks and revelations.  The Irish Catholic chauffeur turned estate agent and adopted son in law does need to leave the house to make sense.  His love for the Crawleys seems to either be a calculated way to keep a higher status or a sad, insecure rejection of his own class values to keep his daughter in good favor with her mother's people.  Either way he needs to go to America or marry the school teacher and live in the village.  I am tired of the gay guy being the bad guy, and it would be nice if he met a railroad employee and ran off to find love, but no chance?  Cora is nice, but her people are awful. I am an American and I hate the intrusion of her relatives into this period piece fantasy.  It does highlight the tragedy of the aristocracy at the mercy of market capitalism and populist politics in the 20thc.  Ah well, banking, finance, diplomacy and maybe non-profit management are open to employ them.  Which man will win Lady Mary's hand in the next season?  Will Granny leave the show by God's hand? Will the little bastard be discovered and taken into the big house (unlikely, but they did take in the Irish Sinn Fein chauffeur)?
summary: Hot season, full of new stories and surprises

reviewText: I'm not fully finished with season 4 yet but it remains pretty much as interesting as season one."Original UK edition" means that it is uncut and not interrupted by commercials, but yes, if youbought it in the States (like on Amazon) then it will play on North American format players.  Igot the Blu-Ray edition and WHY NOT, when some of the best aspects of this series are thestunningly beautiful interiors and costumes?  Also the countryside scenes--all these thingsshine better in higher definition (while of course close-ups of faces show more blemishes).What, bad people don't get dismissed from service?  Gee I've never heard of that happeningin REAL LIFE!  What--people believe malicious gossip?  I never heard of that either!Besides the costumes, the interiors and the scenery, what keeps the series interesting isa combination of two things: A portrayal of how the after-effects of World War I devastatedthe old English nobility, and rather realistic portrayals of people, the "good" ones having theirfaults, and the "bad" ones having their positive features as well.  In short, it has a lot thatresonates with real life, but all with a grander setting.Did I mention the acting remains superb?  And thankfully there are subtitles for those whohave a hard time following everything by soundtrack.  There are about 30 minutes of"bonus features" on the DVD / Blu-Ray.

reviewText: Okay. Matthew's dead. My favorite reason for watching Downton Abbey: the romance of Matthew and Mary. But Don Stevens wanted to go, and he felt like there's nothing left to tell, and he couldn't be put into the position of being out of the spotlight perhaps.. With Matthew around and the other events that took place in Season 4, it would've been better... however...This season just grew darker. As people may've mentioned. I fear if season five continues this descent, Downton Abbey will move from its usual-bright, season predecessors, to joining the ranks of what fills TV now, and that is dark, dark shows with little nuggets of hope and bright-points far and few between.I know the light-heartedness couldn't last forever with Downton Abbey, and if that's the case, I think Downton Abbey should've joined the usual British-tv routine of just retiring the show while it enjoys international acclaim, and letting its memory live on as a warm-hearted series. Instead, as I said, I fear that us people addicted to the story of Downton Abbey might be forced to see a good show go dark. I hope that this isn't the case.
summary: Buy it, If For the Sake of the Story

reviewText: I am completely hooked on the Downton Abbey series. Season 4 does not have the heart-break of season 3. (Thank goodness.)Rose is a real charmer. Tom Branson wanders around looking lost.  I have admired him the most in past seasons.  He is climbing a very long ladder.  There is hope for him.  Sadly, Lord and Lady Granthem have become part of the background.  Come on! He is an English Earl, there is a lot more to his story.  Finally, there is Mosely and the Lady Edith.  They have the best story lines and the best performances this year.  Lady Edith has finally stopped being Poor Edith.  There are no roses but she finds strength and quality in loving, losing, and loving again.  Good Job!
