reviewText: NO ONE KNEW what to expect in Season 4 of “Downton Abbey” – only that the show would go on even though actor Dan Stevens, who played Matthew Crawley, husband to Lady Mary (Michelle Dockery), refused to renew his contract in hopes of pursuing other projects.“Downton Abbey” executives, cast and fans took the news hard. The relationship between Matthew and Lady Mary had been the heart of the internationally popular show. In the “Meet the New Cast,” Hugh Bonnevill, who plays Robert, Earl of Grantham, says, “It did feel strange coming back here … to film the first scene a few weeks ago and realizing there was a gap. But, I’m sorry guys, no actors are indispensable, and the show and the house and the estate is bigger than any of us.”Executive producer Gareth Neame agrees. Losing a main character is difficult, but now there’s a new story about a woman trying to rebuild her life.That’s the heart of Season 4, watching Mary and the rest of the family and servants get on with their lives. It begins just as we would expect; Mary’s father, Robert, wants to shelter his daughter – and Mary is in the mood to be coddled. Former chauffeur, now brother-in-law Tom Branson (Allen Leech) encourages Mary to take part in running the estate. It’s the Dowager Violet (Maggie Smith), Mary’s grandmother, who tells her, she alone can choose her fate.While Mary decides between a life of mourning or activity – and Branson continues to worry about his place in the world and how it might affect his daughter – Lady Edith (Laura Carmichael) gets a chance to shine. Previously plain and unlucky in love, Edith sparkles in a gorgeous new wardrobe and her ongoing relationship with journalist/publisher Michael Gregson (Charles Edwards), who gives Robert a helping hand when least expected. Still, as Edwards explains in the “New Cast” feature, Gregson has something of a dark past and Edith’s problems may not be over yet.As “Downton” enters the Roaring ‘20s – with a defiant Lady Rose (Lily James) determined to keep her family screaming – we are introduced to talented black jazz singer Jack Ross played by Gary Carr. It’s easy to see where Rose wants to go with this (What doesn't work is the family’s reaction to the relationship; frankly, it’s not in keeping with the period.) Among other newcomers are two potential suitors for Mary, Lord Gillingham (Tom Cullen) and Charles Blake (Julian Ovender), both engaging and likable. “I would like to see Mary be bossed around and see someone able to handle her,” Dockery says.Love is a motivating factor for those downstairs, too – except for Barrow (Rob James-Collier), who continues to scheme and plot just because he can. He brings in a new ally, Baxter (Raquel Cassidy), but is she willing to play along? Footman Alfred (Matt Milne), who longs to be a cook, continues his role as the unwitting focus of Daisy (Sophie McShera) and Ivy's (Cara Theobold) affections, much to the frustration of Mrs. Patmore (Lesley Nicol) and Mrs. Hughes (Phyllis Logan) – and the confusion of butler Carson (Jim Carter). We also delve further into Bates’ (Brendan Coyle) unique skills.As a fan, there is nothing like watching “Downton Abbey” on Blu-ray. The picture is so much more intense, colorful and detailed than in broadcast, even on an HD-TV. Few films – especially TV series – show off their visual riches as well as “Downton” with its lavish costuming and scenic locations. (Yes, as standard, the season finale takes us to a lavish party with all the eye-candy.) The 2.0 DTS-MA sound mix remains standard, since the show is largely made up of dialogue, which comes through beautifully. Background music usually emphasizes dramatic moments – by now, we all know the cues – but the jazz moments are clearly defined. As always, these are the unedited British shows, available on both the Blu-ray and DVD.There are 3 discs in the Blu-ray and DVD sets, and 9 episodes. HD bonus features are brief, each about 10 minutes long. They include “Downton Diaries,” a video diary of a day on-set led by Sophie McShera, and a making-of feature exploring Season 4, with an emphasis on costumes. The best is “Meet the New Cast,” that introduces the new actors and their characters, and provides a look at how Season 4 came together.Creator/writer Julian Fellowes gives viewers time to acknowledge Matthew’s loss, then masterfully leads us into the new plot threads and characters. It leaves me hoping that Fellowes will take us much further into the Downton story than the projected Season 5 finale.  — Kay Reynolds
summary: Showbiz tradition takes ‘Downton Abbey: Season 4’ up a new path

reviewText: I've adored this series since it first began. I love the comfort of a more genteel era, despite the occasional modern frustration of watching characters who won't communicate about delicate issues. I watch a lot of historical fiction precisely because it's generally free of the grit and gore that populate modern works.Season Four opened on a bit of a low note. I was saddened by O'Brien's and Matthew's absence, as they both were strong characters on opposite ends of the spectrum. I wasn't pleased to see Braithwaite, because her relationship with Tom seems destined for repetition, and it wasn't very interesting the first time around. His Lordship seems to be retreating into fuddy-duddyhood with all his assumptions, pronouncements, and unilateral decisions that rub wrongly on the other characters.And then, the infamous Episode Three aired.Just. No. Omg, no.The level of violence at the end seemed entirely out of character for the show. The character who performed it seemed to have walked in from a 1970's thriller. His actions seemed illogical and careless, as if he were accustomed to getting away with such violence. Even if the times did support such a conspiracy of secrecy despite facial injuries on various women servants everywhere he went, modern audiences have managed to evolve somewhat. The end result is that the attack scene feels horribly offensive, out of alignment with the show's seasons-long tone, and sewn on from another genre about as subtly as Frankenstein's limbs, All in order to garner controversy, ratings, views, discussion, and other things that drive SEO and publicity.I'm not watching the rest of the season. I'm seriously annoyed at Mr. Fellowes and his outrageous hubris. If you'd stuck to what you're clearly good at, this season would be more entertaining, but apparently ruining a beloved show is your Get Out of Jail Free card, so you can dash off to America to shoot your next project (as mentioned in a Montreal Gazette interview) without having to listen to us poor besotted fans begging you to come back and make more. If you wanted to be rid of us, Mr. Fellowes, you shouldn't have made Season Four at all.
summary: With the greatest respect, Mr. Fellowes, this season's choices are entirely unsupportable.

reviewText: Note: The extras on the DVD were good behind-the-scenes items, but I would have also liked the after-show presentations they had on PBS.  I was really looking forward to those, and that's the only reason I rated this a 4 instead of a 5.)WHEW! a lot happened in Season 4, didn't it?!?SPOILERS (as I address others' comments)-- Regarding Edna, and why `clueless Cora' hired her:  first, obnoxious Rose stepped in (AGAIN) where she was not invited.  And remember, in Season 3  Edna was the clean-up-committee.  She was rarely in a room with the family and she was at Downtown a very brief time.  That's why Cora only vaguely remembered her, which is believable.-- Someone mentioned they don't know where the Edith's baby storyline came from.  It came from the episode where she spent the night with Michael just before he left for Germany.  There, he was set upon by some of Hitler's "brown shirts" and even his newspaper isn't sure what's happened to him.  We watched Edith grow stronger as she makes company decisions for Michael (using her power-of-attorney privileges) and she does all of this while working through a way to hide her pregnancy (Aunt Rosamund to the rescue).  Good to have a show go the adoption route rather than abortion.  Nice touch.-- I DO hope Rose isn't a big factor in Season 5.  O'Brien, Thomas, and Rose are the "Barney Fife" characters in this series, for me.  They become tedious to watch and you wish they'd just go away (which, thankfully, O'Brien did).  Newsflash to Julien, BBC, PBS, etc.:  the younger crowd was watching Downton before you added an obnoxious teenager.  If you keep Rose, could you please make her grow up q-u-i-c-k-l-y and keep the sweet parts of her character?  Othewise, she tiring.-- To a totally different ... and tragic ... topic, they would have lost me if they hadn't come to a fulfilling conclusion after the rape.  An American production would have dragged that on a couple of years.  Dragging in on for a couple of episodes was bad enough.  Once John knew what was going on, we all could relax a bit (instead of the constant "Tell him!" tension.)-- EXCELLENT CHARACTER DEVELOPMENT IN SEASON 4.Joseph Molesley (we discover his first name) becomes much stronger, and Cora's new lady's maid - Miss Baxter - finally tells off Thomas.  I hope they continue the Molesley/Baxter storyline, because they deserve each other in a nice way :->.  Edith is heading to Germany, which has me a little nervous.  "Levinson" is often from a German/Jewish background.  Not sure if that's going to play a part in Edith's safety, going into a bad situation. Do any historians out there know when the Nazis began looking to the nth degree on ancestry for an excuse to kill people?  If Edith stays, she may be in danger.-- Excited for Alfred as he finally makes it to underchef at the Ritz.  His dream-come-true is on its way.  Will he send for Daisy after all (as he once did for Ivy), or will she take up her former father-in-law's offer to take a place at his farm (her inheritance)?  The Daisy/Ivy loggerhead was nicely solved with Ivy heading to America with the Levinsons.  Hoping we'll see more of the Harold/Madeleine relationship.  Julian  left it open.-- Good Mrs. Patmore/Daisy moments throughout the season, which were nice to see.  We discover Carson's long-lost-love.  Julian has given us an impossible choice when it comes to Mary's suitors.  All three are good candidates, but I'm rooting for Tony :->.  I'm hoping his honesty about Charles - when it was to Tony's detriment - gives him some extra points - ha!
summary: "Downton" Sure Packed a LOT into Season 4 !

reviewText: We have enjoyed Downton Abbey since its premier season, and this season continues to entertain us. For example, we were saddened by the attack on Anna, the one truly unselfish and giving character in the story. Her husband Bates' grief when he finally learned the truth, as well as his loving way of handling the situation when he talked with her is an example of the quality writing and acting in this series.  We hope to see Anna emerge with the knowledge that her true identity as a good, incorruptible, and decent woman could never really be defiled, despite the social misconceptions of the time. We hope the writers have Bates lets go of his desire for retribution, and that the perpetrator is made to stand trial. We also enjoy seeing some characters (such as Tom, Lord Grantham, and Lady Mary) grow into better people through what they've experienced and through a change of thought. All of the actors make us care about the lives of their characters.We enjoy Amazon's Instant Video service because we can see the program one day after it airs on public television. Since we don't subscribe to cable or Dish TV, this is the most immediate way fo us to see a current program.

reviewText: Absolutely crackling with inaction, positively palpitating with procrastination, and racing along with all the speed of treacle flowing uphill, this Fourth Series of "Downton Abbey" really doesn't go anywhere, or advance the story much at all.Keep your eyes riveted on the flower arrangements during the first two episodes, because that's where all the action is.And those much talked about production values are definitely slipping.In the second table shot, ...(there are quite a few), eager eyes will notice that the fish knife of the third place setting is slightly askew. (Ho-hum!)Oh and later on even those new-fangled electrical appliances manage to steal every scene they appear in. You know you're in trouble when the gadgets become the stars!It's not until late in episode THREE that anything REALLY happens this time round. (And it's the ONLY significant event in the whole Season too!)Before that it's just long lingering shots of Lady Rigor-Mortis (Mary) mooning and moping about in a semi-comatose state, dressed in her widow's weeds, and walking as though she has a broom handle secreted somewhere within her girdle.She's just SO stiff and cold, and only livens up a little towards the last episodes, .....but it takes a tumble into some pig s*** to achieve this. Even that is so prettily handled that it manages to make the s*** look more like the finest Belgian chocolate. Which I'm betting it was for the shoot!The storyline, ...(if you could call it that), tends to centre on Her Ladyship for this series but her mono-tonal delivery, white white skin, wraith-like appearance and inexpressive acting style are more suited to a haunting.....or a Mrs Danvers role perhaps?The other characters are not given much to work with here.Ladies Maid O'Brian is never seen. Just an anonymous pair of legs and a suitcase doing an early morning flit from Downton at the very beginning of Episode One. We are only told that it was indeed O'Brian that was leaving sometime later on.Bates is reduced to constantly creeping about and lurking in the semi-darkness of the lower corridors looking like some resurrection of Dracula. He doesn't seem to have many duties upstairs as he spends all his time looming from the shadows to accost people and looking positively sinister! His scenes with his wife are actually quite creepy really. He is devoid of any warmth now.Wife Anna manages some very difficult scenes well, ....but the situation she's in then gets stuck into some sort of hiatus and doesn't really develop until the very end five episodes later.Long time devotees of this series will no doubt be pleased to hear that Elizabeth McGovern has maintained her acting style of tilting the head forward and peering myopically through her lashes.It's comforting, because D.A. just wouldn't be the same without that.The script seems to have forgotten that second daughter Edith was developing as a writer when we left Series Three, and having her articles published in a spirit of independence. It's not mentioned at all here.Nor is her once fierce rivalry with Mary.Dead Matthew's Mother Isobel Crawley mutates as we watch from her deep and quite touching mourning into something of a blend between Pollyanna, Florence Nightingale and Mother Theresa.Maggie's Smith's jowl-quivering Dowager is now falling perilously close to caricature, but again she plays it very well, and her better acerbic one-liners can still raise a laugh.Downstairs supervisor Mrs Hughes, who gets some of the best scenes to play, turns in a fine performance, but again, everybody is so "controlled" that all the excessive histrionics are left for the flighty little piece of new fluff upstairs, who is just so gushy and determined to be "thoroughly modern" that she seems to have walked in off the set of some amateur production of "The Boyfriend".(I was expecting her to break into "Won't you Charleston with Me" at any minute!)Her cheesy grinning and over-acting was so supremely irritating and she seemed such an unnecessary and superfluous addition to the cast that I'd have left her back in ye banks and braes of the Scottish Highlands.Dame Tiri Tekanawa has a brief cameo role as Australian opera singer Dame Nellie Melba, although her singing is the butt of some very derogatory remarks made downstairs by the new villain.Oh and if you'd forgotten just how irritating that damned "ding-ding-ding-ding....ding-ding" theme tune can get, .....you are very quickly reminded again. It's repeated endlessly!I call this the "Series of Non-Events".Some examples here in no particular order. ( I have deliberately avoided any mention here of "THE ONE BIG DEAL" in the plot. Anything below is inconsequential.)MINOR SPOILER ALERTS!!!1/ Lady Rigor-Mortis has the opportunity to remarry, and to a very promising man who professes undying love.....but she doesn't.2/Deceased Matthew's recently discovered but unwitnessed will may be disallowed, which would dis-inherit Lady Mary, ....but it isn't.3/The new triumvirate now running Downton are all set to evict the heir of a very long term tenant from his family holding.......but they don't.4/ It looks like a new young gardener is going to be unfairly dismissed for stealing bric-a-brac from Maggie Smith's drawing room, ...but he isn't.5/ Maggie Smith's character is made out to be dying at one stage, ...but of course she doesn't.6/ The ex-chauffeur now part Downton owner Tom Branson feels out of place in the upper class and plans to leave for America with his young daughter , ...but he doesn't.7/ It looks like Tom Branson is to be trapped into marriage by an unscrupulous re-employed maid feigning an opportune pregnancy to marry up into the cushy life, ...but he isn't.8/ It is made to appear that the young footman who has ambitions to be a chef misses his great opportunity at The Ritz, ...but he doesn't.9/ Mr. Molesley, a desperate out-of-work ex-employee who is reduced to working on the roads appears to have missed his opportunity of filling a recent vacancy at Downton, ...but he doesn't.10/ Mr Carson staunchly tries to maintain his decision not to have any contact with his old vaudeville partner, ....but he doesn't.11/ Evil Thomas (yes, he has relapsed since his apparent redemption last season) appears to be planning some great and nefarious scheme to benefit himself, ...but he doesn't.12/ At one stage there are fears that Bates' wife Anna may be pregnant, ...but she's not.13/ That new flouncy young thing at Downton annouces she's going to marry a ....Gasp! Shock!.....BLACK band singer, much to everyone's horror....but she doesn't.There are more than a few other examples, but suffice to say that the plotline consists of so many of these situations that have lots of potential, but then they are just allowed to fizzle out and the story creaks on maintaining the status quo as before.Perhaps some of these ideas may be further visited in ....god help us, ...Series Five?Well what did I enjoy I hear you ask?It must be said that once again there are some most beautiful settings. The apartment of the Aunt in London is truly magnificent. (Furniture and decor to die for!) There are also those aforementioned scene-stealing flower arrangements and of course the exteriors and countryside locations are all breathtaking in their story-book beauty. The briefly glimpsed tenant's farm is immaculate post-card perfection. The vintage cars, motorcycles and London bus are an enthusiast's delight, .....and even of interest to those who just enjoy seeing such well-maintained vintage pieces.The costumes too are truly sumptuous in their detail, ...although some particular dresses get rather too much wear. This may be a continuity problem but I can't see those upper class women turning up in the very same frock again and again in very quick succession.Overall the eight episodes are a quick watch.I managed this in two night sittings, and I guess for me the frustration came from the lack of any real tension, or development of any of the set-up situations. That and the sheer predictability of the thing. You always know exactly where this is going, and that makes it fall into the "coffee-table book" genre.You pick it up just to glance through the beautiful pictures, ...and on that level it succeeds very well.The potential was there for this to be so much more, but Fellowes seems reluctant to carry on his ideas from his initial concept to some sort of interesting narrative.The cast move about in front of the gorgeous settings like stilted paper dolls, ..beautifully costumed to be sure but shackled by the author's restrictive idea of period.Yes, we know that emotions were restrained back then, but it still has to hold interest for the viewer. A cast full of people all so doggedly maintaining that "stiff-upper-lip" do not make for engaging viewing.If half-star ratings were allowed I'd make this a 2 overall, but as they are not I'm giving it the THREE stars, ....and that's primarily for the undeniable visual appeal.There will of course be those who find all I've written above akin to heresy of the very highest order, but mistaking the style that this show has in abundance for substance which is almost totally lacking will no doubt be a common enough error.
summary: The Life of Lady Rigor-Mortis and a Series of Non-Events.

reviewText: The costumes, the scenery, Maggie Smith - my goodness, the old gal is a phenomenon!  The first three seasons were intriguing.  These seem to be dragging a bit, but who can resist all the glitter, the make-up, the hoopla of a generation or a world most of us cannot even imagine.  As for me, I'll go down to the servant's kitchen and drink with the heart of the castle before I retire quietly in the drawing room and listen to some high pitched daughter in a gown that has never been wrinkled sing a very tiring piece of music that would put even the hound to sleep. It's worth it, if you can stand the painful articulation. Never mind that no one blinks.  Long live Maggie Smith!
summary: It may be getting old, but still fun to watch

reviewText: There has been a lot written already, observing that this 4th Season of Downton Abbey is not up to snuff with previous Seasons.  Some viewers may see it that way and that is their right.  All of life changes, evolves and goes through ups and downs.  Life is a roller-coaster ride  -- ever more-so in the 21st Century.  It is the rare enterprise that can sustain a steady, constant ever upward trajectory.  The characters and the crew of Downton are the same stuff of humanity as the rest of us.  If Season 4 may lack the usual gravitas of what we have to appreciate on Masterpiece Theatre, that may be expected and may not come as a surprise.  It must be said that the novelty of Downton, after three (3) Seasons, may have worn off, and viewers have settled in, and it may be more difficult to surprise us.  Life has a way of being life: there are bills, there are struggles to keep and maintain our homes, there is ill-health and death, there are animals that must be cared for.  And there is the ever-present and continuing human drama, comedy, melodrama, and tumult of all of our lives be we aristocracy or servants or regular white and gray and blue-collar average everyday citizens.  There is a slightly different tone to Season 4, but life, whether fictional or real moves on.  None of us in our best days can maintain the quality of life to which we aspire.  Downton and most of British television, film, theatre, music -- the general cultural array -- still outshines American production and production values year in and year out.  America's cultural contributions to the world are now submitted by addled sophomoric fraternity boys and sorority girls.  As the latest report on American ex-patriots indicates, more and more Americans are looking for the exits.

reviewText: Great cast, great story line, excellent characters generally following the arc of history.  I got this set to be able to do the entire season over a single weekend and relish repeating favorite scenes.  As some one who is widely read in history and history of England between the wars, I was interested to see how they adapted to rapidly changing social climate and it was great to have a new character talking about the decline of landed and titled estates.  I could hope that the series goes up through 1939 like the second edition of Upstairs/Downstairs which I finished watching recently.  The general strike, the depression and rise of Fascism in the '20's and '30's would be fascinating, particularly to see how the family reacts to the political contrasts between Chamberlin and appeasement and Churchill and war preparedness.
summary: Another triumphant season at Downton Abbey.

reviewText: 1. Anemic drama. Drama is agon or contest, conflict, clash, disputation, etc., between pro- and antagonist, one of each at least. Even when one side is hostile fate or what the gods, God, history, society, etc., fling, throw against the promulgated hero and his cohort. Even when alleged lackeys and other social inferiors, impudent or inept, pester our dear noble sire, they will have some purpose, cause, justification, inspiration, cleverness, or whatever it takes, to make them worthy opponents, make the drama dramatic.But in "Downton" all potentially dramatic conflict is glossed over, brushed aside, too easily, unconvincingly, like dandruff on the Earl's tux. Even the deaths are convenient. The show is more infomercial than drama -- a soft-core selling of certain country mansions and owners. Has tourist traffic there increased? Do more good citizens see the glamour of the top 1% and understand that they deserve more power? That little people should be happy to serve?2. Strange rituals. A grown man dresses in a tuxedo to visit the bedroom of another grown man and help him, although he is able-bodied, get dressed into a fancier tuxedo, then finishes by brushing dandruff off the man's tux. Solemn, serious, like a religious ceremony. And this today has a fan-club.3. Hollowness of mind. Indicated by the apparent dominance over the Earl of contact language, the function of language we use when we ask the most asked question in our language, "How are you?", and give the most given answer, "Fine, how are you?".  Yes, necessary to some extent to establish that both sides know the language and its little rites of etiquette and are quite willing to obey these for the ease of relations or simply to get going. But what if all other functions of language -- and therefore thought and imagination -- and all social issues become mere extensions of this petty procedure and its superficiality, insouciance, and never go past these limits? When all questions and all answers are only repetition of formalities, customary chit-chat, ritualized trifles, signifying nothing but delusional shine around a hollow core or sordid mess? Call it entropy of spirit. What would Hamlet instead say, in mockery? Or Lear's bright fool?4. The Earl's rite of dinner and coziness of mind and the social hierarchy must not be disturbed -- as if that's the height of all human endeavor: dinner impeccably served. Through the 19th century aristocrats were already portrayed as more often useless or feeble-minded or archaic than not, as educated philistines or hollow costumes on parade, yet still with dangerous power over others, and then were blamed more than others for the blinkered narrow-mindness which led to the disaster known as the Great World War. Yet all this is swept under the fancy rugs of Downton Abbey. Where is the Spanish Inquisition when you need it? And aren't these the people who inspired Monty Python?5. Two antidotes to "Downton":The Remains Of The DayandFanny and Alexander (The Criterion Collecton Theatrical & Television Version). In "Remains" the butler and housekeeper come to recognize that their superb efforts on behalf of the lord of the manor were wasted due to the latter's sheer banality of thought and imagination, too fogged to clearly see the realities confronting him. "Fanny and Alexander" presents drama about European urban haute bourgeoise civilization at its height near the turn of the century, a family engaged both for and against aims beyond smug dinner every day forever.6. Fellini was a master of Dinner Disrupted. I'd love to see what he might have done with one long Downton dinner not going smoothly. When polite chit-chat and haute ritual pigging-out and obedient servants are confronted by something more substantial and subversive, with humor. My imagined scenario: one or two of the daughters on a trip to London meet a gang based somewhat on the Bloomsbury group and associates, and invite them to Downton where dinner then features the Earl and his family and other proper lords and ladies on one side of a long table, and on the other side characters loosely based on Virginia Wolf, her lover Vita, and Lytton Strachey, J.M. Keynes, Clive Bell, Bertie Russell and Alfie Whitehead, and T.S. Eliot and Aldous Huxley, and Lydia Lopokova too . . .  After more than a few drinks, the guests become impudent, more lewdly loquacious, confrontative and rambunctious. It will end very badly of course, interestingly so. Set it in that cruelest month, April.7. There are many buildings more admirable than Downton Abbey née Highclere Castle. The Scrovegni Chapel in Padua was financed in hope of atonement by a wealthy family famous for usury and therefore fearing punishment in Hell; Giotto's frescoes there offer a vision of Christianity at its best. The Palazzo dell'Accademia in Mantua was built, organized by aristocrats and other eminent citizens to promote knowledge and cultural advancement; its beautiful theater featured science demonstrations as well as art performances (the first musical evening presented a prodigy named Mozart). One can visit houses where Leonardo painted, Beethoven composed, Kafka wrote --all more admirable than the doings at Downton. Or sit in the Theater of Dionysus in Athens, or stand in front of the remains of Simon the Cobbler's shop where Socrates (not well-dressed) and his gang annoyed passers-by and talked of matters, questions unwelcome at Downton Abbey. I'd like to see more dramas set in these places, about these people. And the Baltimore housing projects in the first season of "The Wire" hosted more interesting conversations too.8. "Tell me what you pay attention to and I will tell you who you are" -José Ortega y Gasset. The spiritual crisis of our age is revealed by our difficulty in differentiating between low and high, the slimy or stupid and the sublime, the tacky and the transcendent. Our most slavish, crude or mediocre appetitive inclinations have an easy time masquerading as something else. What's really presented for adulation? Call it Golden Calf Worship. Coarse Consumerism Dressed Up But Going Nowhere.
summary: Notes on loathing, ridiculing "Downton", and looking elsewhere.

reviewText: I yield to no one in my appreciation of Julian Fellows's genius.  Downton Abbey is the best thing I've seen since I can remember and Season Four is terrific.  After all the turmoil and tension and bad feeling and heartbreak displayed in Season Three, Season Four comes as a healing wave.  The outstanding characteristic of this season is the flood of love that surrounds this house.  There are all kinds of non-romantic love duos: Violet and Isobel; Rosamund and Edith; Violet and Edith; Mary and Tom; Mrs. Patmore and Daisy, and others.However, as wonderful as this sense of peace and love is, I find that Julian Fellows has gone off the rails once again and written a scenario that is so implausible as to be unbelievable and this one is the latest in a trend.  Once a year Fellows flits off into never-never land and writes a scene that is impossible to credit.  First was Bates's trial; then we had the episode with Tom Branson's drugged cocktail and now there is the attack scene in Season Four.  Since the producers of Downton Abbey tell us in the bonus material how careful they are to be historically accurate why isn't someone checking Fellow's work before it is produced.Consider:  with young women today and even teen-aged girls engaging in every kind of sexual activity, with date-rape drugs rampant and after 40 years of women's liberation - men of today look at women very, very differently than did the men of the 1920s.  Most women in the 1920s came to marriage a virgin.  Women were cherished.  Women were protected.  In this environment, therefore, there is no way that a visiting servant would think that he could attack one of the Downton Abbey staff and get away with it.  The perpetrator would have to assume that the victim would tell the housekeeper who would tell the butler who would tell Lord Grantham and although the perpetrator probably wouldn't have been lynched, at the very least he would have been horsewhipped.  Only the viewing audience knows why the victim wouldn't have told anyone and I can assure Julian Fellows that none of us passed that information along to the perpetrator.Under no circumstances would the perpetrator have returned to the concert, bid his victim good night and casually sauntered into breakfast the next day unless he was insane.  He would have been anxious to put as much distance between Downton Abbey and himself as quickly as possible.  I am not asserting that women were never attacked in the 1920s but this scenario as written is completely unbelievable.I cannot understand why Julian Fellows, as hugely talented as he is, goes off on these weird tangents every so often and writes material that is so obviously impossible.  These bouts of irrationality are becoming a trademark.  There is another coming up in the 2013 Christmas Special in which a 21-year-old Rose will have her debut season.  I wrote about this in the review of the 2012 Christmas Special where it was hinted at.We were introduced to Rose at the end of Season Three.  She was 18.  In the 2012 Christmas Special "one year later" Rose was 19.  Season Four is six months later and Rose is 19-20.  The Christmas Special for 2013 is going to be about Rose's debut season and will take place in the following year: Rose will be 20-21.  Here we have another ridiculous implausibility.  The only reason why the Marquess and Marchioness of Flintshire would not have had their daughter presented when she was 18 - as everyone else did - was if she was in a sanitorium in Switzerland with TB - or for some equally serious medical reason.Fellows doesn't even try to explain why the girl was not presented along with all the other 18- year- olds; why her parents would have flouted tradition.  He ignores reality again and again and then boasts of the historical accuracy of the series.  I wonder if there are two Julian Fellows - one rational, talented Dr Jekyll and an irrational persona who every so often comes to the surface and writes material that is so ludicrous as to be unbelievable.  A 21-year-old debutante would be the laughingstock of the season.  Poor Rose.
summary: Great - but Julian Fellows is off the rails again

reviewText: I'm not purchasing Season Four because it is such a huge disappointment.  Frankly, when Dan Stevens chose to leave the series the intelligent move on the part of Fellowes and the producers would have been to hire another actor to play "Matthew" so that the storyline of his and Mary's marriage and Matthew's moving into the role of running the estate could have been continued because Matthew was the "future" -- he was the young professional class -- an attorney -- who had inherited an estate and married into the aristocracy and at the same time saw that Branson, his Irish servant class  brother-in-law, was going to be a partner in the modernizing of the Downtown estate.  There were many stories that could proceed from that -- but by "killing" the character of Matthew,  Fellowes basically "killed" the core of the series.  Frankly, if he was going to kill the Matthew character, he may as well have ended the series altogether because the writing and plotlines in season four so far -- are inferior and reflect bad daytime soap opera writing.  Only the Dowager and Matthew Crawley's mother have any good lines and far too few IMO,  having Anna raped and then treat Bates like dirt in order "to save him from himself" for fear he would attempt to avenge what happened to her is a moment of "jumping the shark" which no series can afford to do and keep its audience.  The introduction of Edna as Cora's maid had no point.  The new ladies' maid appears to have a shady past -- so once again we are supposed to believe that the Granthams are so stupid that they'd continually hire terrible people to work for them when very obviously in the past they were smart enough to hire very good staff like Mrs. Patmore, Anna and Bates, Carson, Daisy, Alfred and Mrs. Hughes.  The character of Thomas remains static -- he's still a wretched man despite the fact that various members of the family and staff have shown compassion toward him in his time of despair at having been revealed to be homosexual in age when it could result in arrest and imprisonment.  Thomas has never been revealed to be a "stupid" man so one would assume that over time, he would change for the better as he realized that the entire world was not set against him -- nonetheless, once again he is thoroughly unpleasant this season and -- worse -- his character is now boring.I cringe at the knowledge that later this year the godawful Shirley Maclaine and her godawful character will return -- she's like nails on chalkboard -- and this time she'll be toting along Paul Giamatti -- ugh!I think the best thing we can all do now is enjoy re-watching the first three seasons which were entertaining despite being soap operaish -- because now it's just a soap opera and not terribly entertaining soap opera.

reviewText: I read the reviews before purchasing season 4 of "Downton Abbey," so I was prepared for a downbeat season. The main characters, whom we've come to know and love, are mostly present. However, Siobhan Finneran as Miss. O'Brien and Dan Stevens as Matthew Crawley are missing. I read that Stevens wanted off of the show. He is much missed in this season. I don't know why Miss O'Brien left the show. She is also sadly missed as one of the most interesting actors and characters in the show.The plotline of season 3 was a bit weak, and season 4 is weaker still. And yet I still love the series and hope its writers can come up with a more engaging 5th season. We have come to love the extended family and want to follow them through their lives. The acting is superb. The costumes and sets are a treat to the eyes. The camera work is excellent. The musical theme tugs at our emotions. Hopefully, season 5 will take us back to the better writing of the first two seasons.
summary: The least interesting season so far

Title: N/A

reviewText: I have nothing but sympathy for Julian Fellowes. Last season, "Downton Abbey" lost two lead characters when the actors portraying them decided they wanted to leave the show. No one could have anticipated that, so Season 4 of the show is really a rebuilding season. I was very, very worried for the first half of the season, which is just....really bad. Things do pick up considerably halfway through, but I still think this is the weakest season of the show by far. Without giving too much away, there is a terrible plot involving Anna that I absolutely hated...LEAVE THE BATES'S ALONE!!!!Many of the other plots this season are either bad, annoying, or just downright stupid. Daisy has never been my favorite character, but the dull love triangle between her, Ivy, and Alfred quickly grows tiresome. Edna returns to Downton for a stint as Cora's new lady's maid, and she is such a troublemaker! I hate her! Edith has always been an annoying and stupid character, and her storyline takes some ridiculous turns this season. Fellowes couldn't even really come up with anything original for her; he just recycles another character's storyline from earlier in the season. I also think that Maggie Smith is drastically underutilized for the first half of the season (fortunately she compensates for it in the later episodes, with some of her best zingers to date). Sherley MacLaine returns for the final episode reprising her role as Cora's mother, and again I was very disappointed in her performance, feeling that she was vastly underutilized. Paul Giamatti's guest role as Cora's brother is slightly more interesting, but just kind of odd.The best thing about the season by far is Lady Mary's storyline, focusing how she deals with Matthew's sudden death and takes on a more central leadership role at Downton. While I loved the Mary/Matthew romance and was very sad when Dan Stevens departed from the cast, I have come to believe that Matthew was sort of holding Mary back. We see more of the old Mary this season, the strong, unyielding Mary, who will likely be the reason for Downton's survival. There's also some romance as Mary considers getting back into the dating game, but she takes the whole courtship thing slow. We are left with two primary suitors for Mary, and while they're both okay blokes, I have to wonder if someone better suited for Mary might come along next season.Another surprise for me this season was how entertaining Rose's character has become. She was super annoying last season, but provided some much-needed comic relief this time around. Also, Isobel has always irritated me to no end, but that wasn't the case this season. Her character undergoes a bit of a transformation as she copes with the death of her only son and slowly returns back to life. Penelope Wilton delivers some great performances.Aside from Anna's tragedy, there wasn't anything super shocking this season. I think Fellowes let the audience off easy, and Season 5 will probably consist of many more deaths and dramas. I hope that's the case, and that it's much better than Season 4.

reviewText: What can be said of Downton?  The stories are compelling, the characters continue to grow and reveal their strengths and weaknesses.  Lady Rose is a nuisance but Mrs. Crawley is the star of this whole season.  Her humanity and love for all her neighbors is sterling silver. Violet continues to be the spice of DA but even now has a more loving and humane character than she displayed in the previous seasons.  Mrs. Hughes may be the finest example of highest womanhood and courage.  If there is no fifth season, I am willing to be content; if there is there are so many loose ends to be tied up!  DA is the finest drama series in the history of television!

reviewText: I was flabbergasted by the recycled dialogue, the lack of spark that now exists between this ensemble of suburb actors. I think Mr Fellows has seriously lost a handle on what drew me to this sensational show to begine with. Somehow the honesty, and humanity of all characters had me identifying and hanging on the edge of my seat. Nothing happened in this episode ,expect Mary moping, a nanny gets sacked because of Thomas' continuing bad behavior, Valentines cards have all the excitement of a wet edition of the daily paper. There is even a sense in Dame Maggie Smith that the zingers she has excelled at , are not filled with the insouciant humor that has marked all of her remarks in the past and she is frankly not sure how to bring them off any more than she can. The changes in dress, machines, etc are done rather than with a sense of humor mixed with anxiety practically without emotion. I am astonished that this series could so completely lose its delicate balance of ensemble acting, fine writing, visual feasts , to become practically mundane. My goodness what has happened Mr. Fellows ?
summary: plummet down the stairs of downtown !
Title: N/A

reviewText: I've been chewing on these thoughts for a while and it's time to write them down. This is going to be a bit of a rant. In general, I felt that the writers basically repeated all of the same gimmicks from earlier seasons. Below you'll see what I mean.SPOILERS AHEAD!THE REPETITION:1. Thomas is still a jerk (Thomas is the token jerk throughout the series, but he at least enlisted our sympathies in season 2 and 3).2. Thomas still has uncanny power to influence the thinking of the gentry he serves, and they never question it, EVER. (re: every season)3. Uh oh, did Bates murder that guy or not?? (re: season 2 where we wondered if he had killed his wife)4. Speaking of Bates, he certainly knows a little about unsavory activities (re: season 3 when he's in prison)5. SCANDALOUS BABY ALERT! Fine, at least this time it was in the family instead of the servants (re: season 2, with Ethel)6. One of the servants is trying to better themselves again, specifically Alfred (re: season 1 when Gwen became a typist)7. Branson and Edna sittin' in a tree... but not really (re: season 3; why the heck did they even bring her back?)8. Lots of kitchen jealousy concerning Daisy, the guy she likes, and how it's unreciprocated (re: season 1, then again in season 3)9. Daisy once again gets an opportunity to leave Downton (re: season 3 when she was going to move in with Mr. Mason)10. Are Carson and Mrs. Hughes going to get together or not? All these romantic overtones and no follow through (re: every season, but can't remember specifics)11. Assorted men are pining for Mary, and they are willing to break off their other relationships for her (re: every season). On a side note, I NEVER understand why. She's a very disagreeable person, snobby as all get out, and not particularly interesting.12. Not ANOTHER scandalous relationship! (e.g. Lady Rose with the black singer, re: every season has a nontraditional relationship that makes all the high class ninnies gasp and gossip)13. Poor Mr. Molesley gets the short end of the stick, ALWAYS (re: every season since we first met him)14. Poor Lady Edith can never catch a break in her love life (re: every season)15. Good ol' rebellious Rose does everything she can to frustrate the expectations placed on her (re: season 3)OTHER THINGS I DIDN'T LIKE:1. Anna is so righteous and innocent, and then you're going to have her abused like that? Such poor taste. I felt it was a cheap trick the writers came up with to shock us all, when maybe a lesser character would've been a better choice. I think they realized they didn't have the material to keep this season interesting, so they threw this in hoping to bolster the lack of drama.2. Thomas' motives for attacking Anna and Bates, as well as his hold over Baxter, felt completely contrived.3. Everyone is incredibly two-dimensional. In earlier seasons we sympathized with Mary, Lord Grantham, Cora, even Thomas, and honestly most of the characters. We also learned of the depth of Daisy, Carson and Mrs. Hughes. This season, I cared about NONE of them, excepting Anna and Bates (Bates only at the beginning), Lady Edith and Isobel Crawley. All the characters have the same mannerisms they've always had (I especially loathe Cora's peering-over-the-top-of-her-glasses-crooked-smile look, even though she isn't wearing glasses), they all say and do what you expect them to, and they have all the same problems. It felt like I was just watching everyone simply do their jobs and flit about with their usual petty squabbles. I couldn't even force myself to care.4. Branson was so FAIL in this season. Yes, I get that he needed to struggle with the death of his wife, but he was so whiney the entire season "waah, I don't fit in", "waah, I'm so lonely", "waah, should I leave or not?", "waah I don't have a political opinion any more". He starts a somewhat romantic interest with a smart girl he meets at a rally, but they don't develop that at all in the season.5. I also get frustrated with how EASY it is for the servants to sabotage each other (Spratt sabotaging Mr. Molesley, Thomas trying to sabotage everyone and succeeding, and something with Baxter blaming someone else for a mistake that was made sewing, can't remember exactly)6. I also didn't care about any of the characters they added, especially at the end.7. The pacing was better in the earlier seasons. I felt I knew who was who, what they were doing, and it all mattered. This season it seemed like they kept our heads spinning with numerous characters and problems, most of which didn't make any sense at all. I also never understood why they were having the parties they were having at Downton. It just felt like a hodge-podge of characters and activities. Maybe I just didn't really pay attention.THINGS I LIKED:1. I think Lady Edith is my favorite character. First of all, she rolls with Mary's unmerited disdain for her rather graciously, she has significantly more depth than the other characters, and she FINALLY found love, though of course it was destined to fail anyway.2. Isobel Crawley managed to add a dimension this season. I've been irritated by her in every season, up until Matthew died. It's good to see her humbled and be something other than holier-than-thou.3. I found Bates forgiveness/understanding towards Anna after everything went down rather moving. Even though I hate what happened to Anna, I felt the writers dealt with the intra-marital processing of it rather well. It was probably the only moment in this season where I felt something.Overall, I this this was an incredibly lackluster season that recycles what they've already done. Downton has lost its magic for me. I loved seasons 1-3, but something died in this one. It'll be interesting to see if they can recover it next season. I'm not getting my hopes up.

reviewText: Killing off Matthew is a MAJOR err on the part of the producers and directors. The elders in this season are becoming comical instead of compelling. The fury to add NEW characters to this season are seem to be shallow and of no real interest. Let's face it, in the past episodes we cared about the good guys and despised the the mean-spirited, corrupt characters. Now we're beginning to think it's the writers who are mean-spirited and struggling to find issues to keep the series going.It would have been far more entertaining to see Tom and Matthew work together to save the Abbey and to work for women's rights in merry old England. It would have been far more entertaining to see the doctor and Matthew's mother become an item and work together. It would be far more entertaining to see Daisy become the landowner of her father-in-laws estate and build to something large and in competition to the Abbey or at least the Abbey needing her services.The niece or whoever she is, is just plain boring, we don't care if someone would kidnap her. In fact, please do we've had enough already.Season Four is starting off with a whimper.  Good thing Sherlock is beginning soon.
summary: Season Four Taking a Down Turn

reviewText: Downton Abbey is so engaging and enthralling and just keeps getting better and better.  I love the way it engages what i believe to be the actual unfolding of the 20th century, not only in that culture, but how the North American culture was at the same time and the actual ties that bind.  I remain enamored with the personal discipline of the Lords and Lady's and feel that those same values have never gone out of date or style.  Therefore, I love seeing it emulated as a reminder to me of the discipline of holding to my own values.

reviewText: UPDATED:  I re-viewed this Season 4 DVD recently (hoping that my opinion would change - but that isn't the case) and realized that it is missing key scenes.  For example: when everyone is leaving the house party, the scene where Gregson, Samson, and Edith are talking and Gregson returns the IOU to Samson - that ENTIRE scene is missing. There are others missing as well but I don't want to give out any spoilers. So if you think you are purchasing an UNCUT version, this is NOT it.  This same thing happened with the Season 3 DVD (several key scenes are missing).  I don't understand why they eliminate scenes on the DVD version???I'm  a HUGE fan of this series and couldn't wait until Season 4 premiered here in the U.S.  I already own Seasons 1 thru 3 so when Season 4 was released for sale on Jan. 28, I immediately purchased it.  I won't be giving any spoilers, however, suffice it to say that this Season 4 is just downright TERRIBLE!  There are plot lines that are SO unbelievable you have to scratch your head and wonder if Julian Fellowes and his writers were smoking something.  Example:  in one episode, a character has a huge problem and then the next episode is over 1 year later and the problem is "solved" and all we get is an explanation via words.Also, Mary has a couple of men interested in her which provides a good story line, however, the first man gets reacquainted with her after many, many years and 3 days later he's professing his undying love for her.  What???You never get a sense that any of this is believable because it happens SO quickly -- we're never allowed to see the relationships develop like they did between Mary and Matthew or Sybil and Tom or even Anna and Bates.  It's like Julian Fellowes is unsure whether the series will be picked up for another season, so he tries to cram tons of script (much of it unnecessary and not believable) into each episode.And frankly, the sarcastic-ness between Old Lady Grantham and Mrs. Crawley is really getting very old.  In this Aeason 4, Mrs. Crawley helps Violet to a great degree, yet Violet remains her nasty self with Isobel.  Also, we all know that Bates "saved" Mr. Barrow in Season 3, yet Barrow still continues to be nasty to Bates and Anna.Lastly, there are some really stupid story lines in this Season 4.  Surely Cousin Rose isn't a total idiot, yet she continuously makes stupid and hurtful decisions again and again.  It's like they gave her a mind of a 4 year old.  And yet once again, Tom Branson is having difficulty adjusting to his life as part of a rich family.  Really??? Hasn't he been living at Downton for the past 3-4 years?  That story line should have been signed-sealed-delivered ages ago.  Enough with that.And if I hear the words "pig man" one more time, I'll scream!What I liked?  the clothes, the set decoration, the old cars, and the story line between Alfred (the under-butler) and Daisy, the assistant cook.This Season is on 3 discs and contains "The London Season" which is the 2 hr concluding episode of this Season 4.
summary: BE WARNED.....this DVD is missing lots of scenes!!!

reviewText: Many people go crazy over Cheetos, but few of the Cheetos fanatics would ever claim that Cheetos are actually "good."  They recognize that their favorite junk food is basically crap.  I doubt if they'd go on line and give Cheetos a five-star rating because they recognize a distinction between what they like and what is good.  When it comes to the arts, though, people are unable to make or even consider any such distinction.  If they like it, it's "good."  You'll hear that a classically terrible movie like "Plan 9 from Outer Space" is "so bad it's good."  This is, of course, impossible: an excess of bad doesn't equal good. What they mean, of course, is it's "so bad it's enjoyable."Like  millions of other people I watched  the first three seasons of "Downton Abbey" religiously every week.  But I knew it was silly nonsense full of idiotic plot twists.  In a review of these seasons I pointed out its stupidity, but I gave it three stars anyay, as a sort of compromise between its quality and its watchability.  But I finally gave up in the fourth season, and now I can happily report I'm as free of Downton Abbey as I am of Cheetos. I'm not going to rehearse the absurdities of the plot, but let's have a little fun with the worthless characters.  Here are a few of the characters we are supposed to care about:*.  The Earl of Grantham--a cross between the silly-ass, clueless aristocrat best captured by PG Wodehouse in his novels about Lord Emsworth and his pig and the equally clueless, pompous, self-righteous fathead Lord Darlington in "remains of the Day."*  his wife--Here the problem is not so much the characters as the actress. Elizabeth McGovern.  I've never met anyone who could stand that sweet/sad crooked smile of hers.You just want to hit it with a Boston Cream Pie.*  Carson the butler-- See comments about the Earl.  We are asked to believe that he was once a music hall performer who was abandoned by his true love.  I prefer to think he is a priest defrocked for his inability to keep his hands off the choirboys.* Bates--Oh come on!  This character makes no sense at all.  In this fourth season he travels to London by train to kill his wife's rapist.  But the shmuck neglects to destroy the ticket stub that proves he was in London! In fact, he leaves it in his coat pocket.*Dowager Countess of Grantham--Maggie Smith was the only reason to watch the first season.  She was, of course,, playing a version of Lady Bracknell from "the Importance of Being Ernest."  But they've softened the character to such a degree that she no more fun.* Lady Edith Crawley (Matthew's mother)--There used to be (and for all I know still is) a comic strip called "Mary Worth,"  whose eponymous heroine kept interfering with everybody's else's life.  (I remember a MAD Magazine parody in which someone asked her, "What do you do actually beside sticking your nose in everybody else's business?")  Well, here she is, little Miss Do-gooder*Tom Branson--This is the Irish Catholic Socialist revolutionary chauffer who improbably marries one of the daughters. The actor's Irish accent reminds me of what the Harvard Lampoon said of Ryan O'Neal in "Barry Lyndon":  "His Irish accent wouldn't fool Fernando Lamas." Now I know the actor is from Dublin, but I'm from Brooklyn and I don't sound like Sheldon Leonard or Tom Pedi (anyone remember them?)Well, that was sort of fun (for me at least).  If you want a really good british series, try "Mr Selfridge."  It's as enjoyable as this one and you don't feel like you're eating a bag of Cheetos.
summary: Why is Downton Abbey like Cheetos?

reviewText: The fourth season of "Downton Abbey" (not including two Christmas specials) attempts to recapture some of the original spark that made its first season such a success, and comes about as close as it’s ever going to get. After the trauma of World War I and the deaths of two beloved family members (sadly necessary due to the actors leaving for other projects), the show can settle down and become the frothy soap-opera that it’s always been at heart. Only now, no one is pretending that it’s anything else.SPOILERS BELOWSet in the mid-1920s, the fourth season opens with Mrs O’Brian sneaking away in the night, another causality of an actress deciding to call it quits – though in this case, at least she made it out alive – and Countess Grantham starting the search for another lady’s maid.  Fellowes wisely decides to open the season six months after Matthew’s death in a car accident, thus sparing us the rawness of his passing (it was painful enough with Sybil), and depicting Mary as a young widow who believes she has little left to live for.From start to finish this season is packed full of your favourite melodrama tropes: love triangles, out-of-wedlock pregnancy, murder, rape, doomed relationships, half-orphaned children, impassioned declarations of love – it’s all here, and it’s embraced with a whole-hearted awareness of how silly it all is. And I honestly say that with affection. I don’t watch “Downton Abbey” for historical accuracy or sophisticated plots or – heck – even character development. I watch because it’s light, glossy, pleasant fluff. No apologies.But season four turns out to be something of a mixed bag. Though I enjoyed the depiction of Mary’s movement from bleak despair to a renewed interest in life, I wasn’t at all impressed by her new bevy of suitors (in fact most of the time I couldn’t even tell them apart). Hapless Moseley and long-suffering Edith are once again put through the wringer, but this time they face their tribulations with spunk and fortitude, giving audiences a good reason to cheer them on.Poor Tom Branson used to be such a firecracker, yet now he keeps falling miserably into the machinations of calculating women, and whatever character development was afforded to Thomas has now been obliterated in favour of once more making him Downton’s resident puppet-master (how he still has a job is beyond me). The tedious love triangle between Daisy, Ivy and Alfred continues to stretch on downstairs, boring everyone including the participants, and poor Daisy keeps shutting down the prospects that open up all around her (Gwen was allowed to leave Downton in order to pursue career opportunities elsewhere – why not Daisy?)Yet contrary to what most viewers seem to think, I quite enjoy Cousin Rose and her light-hearted hijinks, though Lord and Lady Grantham continue to be the most oblivious people on the planet. I’m sure that Cora used to be the sharpest and most observant member of the household – now she’s an utter dimwit who consistently trusts the wrong people and doesn’t notice the most obvious occurrences happening right under her nose.Something truly lovely comes out of the Violet/Isabel relationship – at the start of the show they were so at odds with one another, and now something very close to a prickly friendship has formed (though neither one of them would ever admit it). That goes ditto for Mary and Anna’s friendship of quiet respect and support, and of course, the “platonic marriage” that exists between Carson and Mrs Hughes; surely the backbone of the entire household.All that said, there is one particularly dark point during the course of the season that was met with outrage and disgust from “Downton” viewers, and that was the controversial rape of one of its most popular characters at the hands of a visiting valet. Anna has been the moral centre of Downton from the show’s inception, and though we (mercifully) don’t see the act itself, the build-up and the fallout is harrowing enough, coming as quite a slap in the face to unsuspecting viewers. That Anna was chosen as the “victim” of such a crime was a strategic ploy, knowing that she was loved and admired by the audience. Would the controversy have been as pronounced, if this storyline had played out between – let’s say – Jimmy and Ivy? I doubt it.The aftermath is even more troublesome, for even though I give Fellowes credit for not victim-blaming Anna or glossing over the trauma that comes in the wake of a sexual assault, the storyline that follows is much more focused on Bates and *his* pain over what’s happened than Anna herself (and Anna’s insistence that Bates not be told what’s happened to her in case he takes revenge on her attacker means that every other woman in the house is put at risk because of BATES’S stubbornness).Yet despite this, there are some highpoints that make up for the sour notes. Violet giving her bereaved grand-daughter a simple “I love you.” The magnificent Mrs Hughes confronting Anna’s rapist. Mrs Patmore expressing to Daisy how proud she is of her. A fun sequence in which Rose strikes up a rapport with a village boy before scurrying to conceal her identity. Several touching scenes between siblings-in-law Tom and Mary, both lost without their spouses and struggling to support each other. And finally, Edith fighting for her right to happiness and taking matters into her own hands when it comes to the future.There are return appearances from past characters such as Evelyn Napier, Charlie Grigg and Mr Mason, and a guest appearance from New Zealand opera singer Dame Kiri Te Kanawa as Dame Nellie Melba. There’s even a long overdue update from Gwen, not seen since the first season.What else can be said other to say that it’s quintessential “Downton Abbey”, with everything you’ve come to expect. As ever, the costumes, set design, score and cinematography are a high-point, all beautifully and meticulously presented to create a visual encapsulation of the mid-1920s. Say what you will about his plotting (or the man himself) creator Julian Fellowes knows how to give his actors witty, breezy dialogue, and though I wish he would pull back on the romance (never his strong point), there are a variety of familial and platonic interactions that are as compelling as they are unique, existing between sisters, in-laws, friends, rivals, and of course masters/servants, the relationship which has always been the bedrock of this show.
summary: “If I was in Search of Logic, I Should not Look for It Among the English Upper Class.”

reviewText: Jan-30-2013 No spoilers here. Last night I finished watching the entire 4th season, and must say that the picture quality of the Blu-rays far exceeds what we see during the PBS HD broadcast. And John Lunn's music, as always, sounds wonderful. While the season may have had some disappointments, noted by myself and others when we began watching early episodes on PBS in the U.S., enough happens in later chapters to redeem it, and while it certainly wasn't perfect, there are sufficient interesting plot points to set the stage for future intrigues in the seasons that will surely follow. And I was pleased with the special features. One point: The final episode is 2 3/4 hours long, referred to as "The London Season," and I was amazed at how quickly those nearly 3 hours flew. And the 3 behind the scenes specials are, in total, about 36 minutes, and even though they fly (because they're so fascinating), they seemed longer than that. I just love this series and now have 4 seasons of it on Blu-ray and my appreciation of it hasn't diminished.

reviewText: My wife and I looked forward to Season 4 with great anticipation, and at first blush we were not disappointed.  We have the same richly textured character interest and the same superb production and acting.  However, we can't avoid a feeling of disappointment as some of the plot lines have slipped into cliches and political correctness. Indeed we have a sense that we have descended into a rather ordinary soap opera, overlaid with our post modern norms and mores.  Whereas the Thomas gay plot line had been handled with sophistication and realism, we now need to be hit over the head with the obligatory racial bigotry bit.  Oh please, we know all about it.  But why include the racial sub plot while ignoring the Irish rebellion that was ongoing at the time?  It is 1922 after all, and the Branson character is portrayed as sensitive to the plight of the Irish worker and workers generally.  While I am at it, it seems that the Branson character's continual playing of Hamlet about his true allegiances has become trite and tiresome in the 4th season.  And along with the racial plot line, we have the equally hackneyed rape story line that hits us over the head yet again by telling us how difficult it was for a poor working girl to deal with a violent sexual attack by someone in a superior social position.Summing up, the series is still well worth watching for its sparkling performances by many of the cast (the interplay between Maggie Smith and Penelope Wilton is pure pleasure), but be prepared for an overlay of post modern cliches that take much of the luster off the goings on.

reviewText: I was going to purchase this set, but after reading about 50 pages of "ratings" I have come to the conclusion that most of these are people who are paid to pump product. reviewText: As I predicted, the series "Jumped the Shark" after the main character, Matthew Crawley, was killed off.  Main plot for three seasons was Mary and Matthew (Michelle Dockery and Dan Stevens had huge chemistry).  Now the plots are getting boring (Ivy, James, Alfred, Daisy=BORING!!!) .  A series "Jumps the Shark" when "long-lost relatives" are added on (Cousin Oliver on Brady Bunch, cousins on Happy Days, cousins and long-lost siblings on Little House on the Prairie, original Beverly Hills 90210).  There was no reason to add Cousin Rose to Downton, when Julian Fellowes could have focused his attention on Mary, Branson and particularly Edith and her relationship with Gregson.  I wanted to see Edith become a famous writer.  The addition of the black character is weak.  The rape of Anna and how it is resolved is extremely disappointing.  Mary's suitor Blake (Julian Ovenden) is poor casting, as the actor is 4 inches shorter than Michelle Dockery (Mary) and it's very awkward.  Three men, all good looking and rich, in their mid to late 30s still single after "The Great War," is unrealistic. The dialogue was terrible "Mary, you fill my head up!"  Please!!!  Edith's baby mess was ridiculous.  Elizabeth McGovern's acting has gotten so much worse (look at her face when Anna and Bates run into her at a restaurant).  Finally, Branson's school teacher lady friend is about 4'9 inches tall and annoying. The camera angle when Isobel and Branson are talking to her is ridiculous.
summary: Once a great series... has now  "Jumped the Shark" with Matthew's lame death.

reviewText: Season 4 was a disappointment as the plots seemed more or less "thrown at the walls" to see what might stick. However as I had previously bought Seasons 1, 2, 3, I felt I had to pre-order this Season in hopes that things would return to the former quality of the story thread in Season 5...when I love a series I don't want to skip Seasons. Really not loving the "rape" angle for Anna and Bates...we covered all the prison aspects already...Just a plot line developed to maybe distract us from the "hole" left by Matthew's departure...ditto the schizophrenic treatment of the character Thomas...he's a creep in the initial seasons, then he suddenly seems changed and repentant now he's suddenly back to being a weasel...What's up with that? Surely we could give the downstairs as seedy screwed up characters a break and move on to how the upstairs is going to save the estate, raise the little ones particularly Mary's child that no one...not the grieving Grandmothers or Mommy bother to visit...again what's up with that...having lost one's son or husband...it doesn't follow that neither would not focus on the child...I don't know but my feeling this season was...Good Lord Fellowes "Keep Calm and Carry On" pick up a story line that's not recycled and is vaguely reminiscent of something other than a tawdry soap...quiet flailing and develop the characters you still have. Photography and acting as always excellent...now they just need a clue and a plot.

Killing off Mathew because the actor wanted out of the series seemed a poor, poor choice, a senseless murder in my opinion. If he'd done a good job we wouldn't have missed his predecessor.Acting, costumes, sets, camera work, music, location, attention to detail...are we sure this isn't a real place and all the men and women real players?  Where the heck is Isis in Season 4?  Did she quit, too? We knew O'Brian had to go, wished it anyway.  Bringing Braithwate back, really, with a new hair color? Glad to see most of the family in tact and downstairs, too.

reviewText: What more can I say about this wonderful series.  We have purchased them all since they came out and will keep adding to our collection as long as they produce it.  If you have not seen Downton Abbey, please start at the beginning of the series and progress.  You will not be disappointed.  Synopsis: Season 4, set in 1922, sees the return of the much loved characters in the sumptous setting of Downton Abbey. It has been six months since Matthew's tragic death and Mary struggles to face the future with her fatherless child, and is encouraged by the family to pick up the pieces.  Mary now finds herself the reluctant object of attention by a number of eager suitors.Cousin Rose is attracted to the bright lights of London which spells trouble for the Crawleys.  Edith's budding relationship with Michael Gregson is threatened by events beyong her control. Downstairs we have Anna who struggles with her guilt of being raped by Lord Gillingham's valet,  Mr. Molesly becomes enarmored with Baxter, Cora's new lady's maid who is somehow beholding to Thomas Barrow, the under butler, who is constantly prodding her to tell secrets she may have heard between the gentry in the Abbey. My favorite character above all is Violet who is played by Maggie Smith.  Take time to sit and watch this series, you will be thoroughly entertained.

reviewText: After the two deaths during Season 3, both after the birth of a child, I began to wonder if the writers of this show were getting pretty lazy.  After watching the first 2-hour episode of Season 4, I now think the writers are writing in their sleep.  When Maggie Smith seems dull, this show is in big trouble.  Then, we have one conflict after another, as if the writers think the viewers will jump up and turn off the TV if something doesn't happen to someone every other minute.  How many conflicts do you need in one 2- hour episode?  That episode is definitely going to make it easier for me to totally stop watching the show, if I decide to do so.  After reading of the horrific thing that is going to happen to sweet Anna in the next episode, there is a very good chance that I am going to do so, too.  Julian Fellowes obviously doesn't realize how many viewers watch "Downton Abbey" for entertainment and escape.  That's too bad and too sad.Afterthoughts 1/14:  I am really going to miss Violet, Edith, Mrs. Hughes, Daisy, Mrs. Patmore, Anna, Mr. Bates, Mr. Carson, Isobel, Dr. Clarkson, Mr. Molesley, Sir Anthony, Ethel and Miss O'Brien.  I did not watch the episode last Sunday night about Anna, and will never watch another new episode.  I am finished.I am finished being jerked around by Julian Fellowes, when he's in the mood to add a strong dose of "realism" to a show that is ironically based on a fantasy--the fantasy  that the upstairs and downstairs residents were like one big, caring family back in the early 1900s. Mr. Fellowes should have stuck to his fantasies, and continued entertaining us with an astoundingly addictive and fun to watch show.No, I will never watch "Downtown Abbey" again unless I read that there is a new episode where all of the characters on the show, including Sybil and Matthew, wake up screaming one night from nightmares . . . only to have all of their terrors quickly disappear. . . when they all fully awake and realize that Season 3 & Season 4 were only bad dreams . . . very, very bad dreams.
summary: The Sleeping Writers Are Creating A Nightmare . . . Goodbye, Downton Abbey . . . .
