reviewText: I was very anxious to see this new season on dvd, and have just finished it. There is some that is pretty good, some that is really good, and sadly, some that is not so good, but even with frustration with some of the plot lines, the acting is for the most part, excellent.SPOILERS..........................SPOILERS.......................SPOILERS......................SPOILERS..............................There seemed to be some reversion to character traits of earlier seasons, which was unfortunate, since we had seen some development. I don't think it was just being with Matthew that "changed" Mary," but I had hoped, some maturing through the war, etc. All that is gone, and Mary is completely cold and self absorbed again. Even though Anna was expected to, and did, help her carry Pamuk's dead body to his room so that Mary's secret might be kept, and even though Bates left his job, his security, his happiness, to return to psychowoman, so that Mary's secret might be kept, when Mary was faced with the choice to keep his or not, what did she tell Mrs. Hughes? "it's a man's life, it's WRONG." She had no proof that Bates was the killer but was that ready to sell him out. ONLY when Bates yet AGAIN saved her family and the monarchy from another embarrassing scandal did Mary change her mind.  Mary is loyal only to her position. Period. It broke my heart, and Carson's, when she was cruel to him. I am glad he got in the last shot. Nor did she tell Anna or Bates what she had done with the ticket, so Bates has to live in worry.I thought there were some layers of human complexity in Thomas last season, but that too is all gone. He is back to being "one note" evil, causing trouble for everyone for no apparent reason. Additionally, the thing with the Nanny was clunky. He was trying to get her in trouble, but she cooked her own goose when Cora heard what she said to Sybbie, which had nothing to do with Thomas. In contrast, the guy who plays him, from what I have seen in the extra features, seems to be a nice guy. He is good at being bad! I wonder what if it had been Tom who heard Nanny, and what he would have done to her. Sadly, there were probably many many children of "privilege" who were at the mercy of nannies and governesses like Nanny West, and even still.I thought it was too bad that both Robert and Cora seemed to suffer from extreme amnesia this season, to the point of seeming demented. First, when Thomas and Braithwaite were pointing fingers at Anna, saying she was being mean, they believe them, even though they know Anna is the sweetest person ever, and is never mean to anyone! They even speak to Bates about her. Totally wrong. It was the same in the scene where Thomas is complaining to Robert about the other staff and Robert said, "are you not liked downstairs?" Never mind that there were incidents of theft and attempts to frame Bates in earlier seasons, and what kind of person Thomas is, which Robert well knows. Amnesia, I say.  Robert and Cora should have laughed Thomas out of the room. Why is he still working there? I was glad Braithwaite got kicked out early on, and loved her smackdown by Mrs. Hughes. Additionally, when Violet was questioning Robert about his wanting total control of the estate, I too was thinking, yeah, because you have done so well with that up til now!"Now Edith. She seems to present as a sympathetic character for alot of people, but she isn't to me. While Mary is not a nice person, she never did anything to really hurt Edith in the first season, yet what Edith did to her by telling the Turkish guy what happened to Pamuk, would have ruined Mary's entire life, if she had not married Matthew. She would have never married and even worse, have been shut out of the society she lived for. I thought it perfect karmic justice that Edith was jilted at the altar, losing her chance to marry, and now experiencing what would cause equal scandal for her. I wanted her to remember what she did to Mary, but the show didn't go there. I have to say that Cora and Mary were pretty blind to not know Edith was pregnant, since they knew she had a boyfriend,had to have started to show, and suddenly off to Switzerland for months. Stevie Wonder would know. I thought Violet's reaction was great.." I see I will have to take the slow path" but not judgmental, nor was she of Sybil and Tom. For all her clinging to the old ways, she was pretty down to earth with her granddaughters and matters of love and sex. It was funny how Robert chastised Dr Clarkson for saying the word "urine" in front of her! Tis a mystery what happened to Gregson. If the Nazis killed him, they would have found a body? They didn't have camps yet in 1922 I don't think. has he faked his death? Why would he give Edith his power of attorney?I didn't like Rose at all. She was a spoiled little rich girl who didn't give a thought to anyone else, but wanted what she wanted. No replacement at all for Sybil, who was a real person, with  brains and a heart. I SO miss Sybil. Matthew was a nice guy but I loved Sybil. I wish that Cora's mother had been there when Sybil was dying. She would have thrown Sir I Know it All out the window, got Sybil to the hospital, and saved her. I absolutely think Dr Clarkson was right and would have saved her, had they listened to him. I agree with Cora, and didn't want her to reconcile with Robert, even though Violet pushed her to. It was completely Robert's and Sir Know it All's fault.I thought the Daisy/Ivy/Alfred/Jimmy adolescent posturings went on interminably, but Daisy and Mrs Patmore's relationship matured, which was nice to see.I got really tired of seeing Molesley whining and feeling sorry for himself. I liked how he stood up for Baxter though, helping her to feel better about herself, and hopefully telling Thomas to go jump in the lake. I see a relationship developing there, no matter what she's done.The pig stuff was dumb. When DID Mary learn to make eggs?Cora's mother and brother stuff was dumb and unnecessary. Also the cloak and dagger spy stuff in trying to get the letter back. If it was that important, maybe girlfriend shouldn't have had it in her bag and then left her bag unattended!What was REALLY good...Anna's storyline, and her acting. She brought it!!! I hope they have British Emmys, she should definitely win. I really wanted her to go to the police after she knew Bates knew though. I thought that she was selling him a bit short for being so sure that he would kill Green, and ruin their lives together. I LOVE Mrs Hughes, she is such a badass! I thought she was going to kill Green with her bare hands, and I bet she could have. Such great scenes with Anna, with Green, with Braithwaite, with Carson. ALL of them. It's such a shock to see her on the show and then how she looks in real life, a decade younger, like Mrs. Patmore. I also love Carson. He is absolutely old school, and is judgmental and rigid and everything else, but it is his job to make sure everything goes right. It was all on his shoulders. He does have a caring heart though. He adores Mary, though I am with Mrs Hughes on that, and I loved the scene with he and Sybbie. One of my favorite scenes was when he had just found out Mrs Hughes was okay, and he was singing and laughing while he polished the platter, so unlike him, but so sweet. The final scene of this season is right up there too, with Carson in BARE feet, wading, and holding Mrs. Hughes' hand for security! Others think they should be married, I don't know, but even if not, their friendship is wonderful to see.I don't think Bates is the killer. It would take alot of things to fall into place to take the train to another town, rent a car, find where the guy lives, follow him to where you would be able to hit him, with no one seeing it, or you, then returning the car and getting back on the train. It is possible he had someone else do it, but they would have the same problems. He was hit by a car right?  I think it was an accident. I wanted someone to kill him, but slowly. I can only imagine how many victims he had. As vulnerable as women have always been to sexual assault, I feel sure that women and girls in service positions were especially easy to victimize.Tom matured this season, I thought. I didn't like him when he was with Sybil. He was controlling, willing to let her sacrifice everything in her life for him but gave up nothing for her,not wanting her to "disappoint him" I hated that, or to have ideas about their child that disagreed with his, and not even treating her family with the slightest respect, when they were sheltering him and even keeping his ass out of prison. I understood and agree with where he was coming from but he could have given Sybil that much.He was a jerk but did start to grow up after Sybil's death.  I think maturity involves the ability to not only see your corner, but the other guy's as well, including the English, and he was getting there. It was such irony to see him dancing at the ball with monarchy. I wonder if the "troubles" are going to rear their head again next season, since one of the guys after Mary has a castle and holdings in Ulster, which I believe is in Northern Ireland. How would Tom deal with Mary becoming an occupier?I LOVE LOVE LOVE Dame Maggie Smith. I love her snarkiness and her wisdom.  Her scenes with Isobel were gold. It was well done how Isobel could have gladly strangled her, yet when Violet was ill, wouldn't leave her side. Even sick, Violet had good lines! The scene where they are playing cards and having fun together is great. I had a sad moment though, in seeing her ill scenes, to realize she is nearly eighty years old. She is a treasure, and always will be.This show is a treasure as well, even with all its faults. It has stellar performances and often excellent writing. I don't compare it in any way with Upstairs Downstairs. This is its own entity, and it is awesome to see how many people around the world love this show.

reviewText: First the bad:As an American I have always hated the way that this series portrays Americans. Why does British tv always pick actors with the worst American accents? They make us sound so odd. And why do we always have to be loud, obnoxious, wide eyed, eager, big mouthed, rude, and effusive? Are we single dimensional?Shirley McClaine only appears in the last episode, but the banter between her character and Violet is stale. It was funny the first time. Now they both just look like harpies.This season moves really fast compared to previous ones. It's bam, bam, bam! This one's in, now she's out. This happens and then it's over. While the pace of previous seasons seemed slow before, now it seems to fit because those were slower times. Maybe that is why they've sped things up. It feel jarring.The good:Basically what is good about it is all the things that we all liked before. There are the spectacular costumes, acting, sets, and historical backdrops. The characters are still interesting. I feel they have replaced breadth for depth, but they are still good. The stories are fresh. You can see how prosperity is returning after the war. I liked the attention paid to Branson's evolution. It will be interesting to see how that plays out. The competition for Mary is also interesting. I thought the pacing for that was good. The final episode was definitely a show stopper. Very grand.

reviewText: Season 4 is "darker" than the first three, especially with the assault on Anna. Even though "she was a nasty piece of work" I miss Siobhan Finneran (O'Brien) who left service at Downton right at the beginning of season 4. Matt Milne (Alfred) has also left. I'm still getting over the departure of Dan Stevens (Matthew Crawley), as is everyone at Downton. And I still miss Jessica Brown Findlay (Lady Sybil Crawley). I know life goes on as actors have other roles to pursue. However, to me, these actors played irreplaceable characters. (If Maggie Smith were ever to leave, I think Downton would be done for.)I also found the first three seasons to be sweeter, more romantic. I wish Thomas (Rob James-Colier) will find a love interest in Season 5. Perhaps then he wouldn't be such a brat!
summary: Downton Abbey season 4 not as good as the first three seasons
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm caught in this British Soap Opera -- pulling for this character, mad at another, hoping Bates won't get caught, etc.  I'm hooked.  The characters are from another age but there are the likable, distasteful, and down right mean people, all mixed up in severly rigid class distinctions and full of intrigues and counter schemes that make me want to watch the next episode.  The end of Season 3 was just horrible (a very nice chap died in a motor car accident) and I couldn't watch it for awhile.  But then I thought, 'That's the way life is unfair stuff happens to the good and the bad guys get away with bad stuff.  BUT I think it all evens out in the end, you reap what you sow!  Downtown Abbey has me hooked.

reviewText: Season four was great as usual. As the beginning started with a bang, the pace some what slowed almost to a fizzle mid way, and sparked back up immediately. The Christmas Special episode was intriguing indeed as the Crawley's invade London for the social season and assist in the presentation of Lady Rose MacClare in the Royal courts to King George V & Queen Mary. I was hoping that the clothes, jewels, and scenery would have been even more elaborate as I'm accustomed to from Julian Fellowes. Nevertheless it was sufficient. Perhaps there were budgetary constraints? I anticipated over the top scenery for a Buckingham palace setting as in those times things were indeed most ostentatious!  The Character Jack Ross who played love interest of Lady rose made things sizzle and a intimate love scene would have been tantalizing indeed.!!!
summary: Another Epic Season 4 wrap for the archives! Cant Wait Until Season 5

reviewText: I watch at the end of the season, so I can view it over several days. I love this show, and the characters. I would have given this five stars except I think the writers got a bit lazy this season. I can see where they borrowed themes from Upstairs/Downstairs. And though these themes might be consistent with the times these shows are set in, this is entertainment not just historical, so I don't want the same thing over and over. Example, the Aristocratic lady and the Black man...Done. The Aristocratic lady giving birth and having the farm hand raise the baby...Done!Another inconsistency that kept me from giving this 5 stars was the Bates family drama. At one point, Mary is handed a train ticket to London that was in Bates' coat. Suddenly that tells her everything? First she says she doesn't mind lying, then suddenly gets over vigilant to protect a rapist's rights. Finally she comes to her senses. That bothered me, and so 4 stars. I hope they ramp it up a bit for season 5. They had a few misses this season. Next season will make or break this series I think...
